title: EFCO v. Renaissance on Charleston Harbor
description: EFCO Corporation appeals an award of attorney fees and costs to Renaissance on Charleston Harbor, LLC in this mechanic's lien action.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
EFCO Corporation, Appellant,
v.
Renaissance on Charleston Harbor, LLC, Estates Management Company, Bovis Lend Lease, Inc., Phoenix Contract Glass, LLC, National Grange Mutual Insurance Company, Harbor Sales, LLC, Point Sales, LLC, Edward Strom a/k/a Edward T. Strom, and Robert M. Mundy, Jr.,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4155
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 2, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Clifford O. Koon, Paul D. de Holczer, and Mary Frances Gibson, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Henry W. Brown and William D. Britt, Jr., both of Columbia, for Respondents Renaissance on Charleston Harbor, LLC, Estates Management Company, Harbor Sales, LLC, Point Sales, LLC, Edward Strom a/k/a Edward T. Strom, and Robert M. Mundy, Jr. 
C. Allen Gibson, Jr. and James E. Weatherholtz, both of Charleston, for Respondent Bovis Lend Lease, Inc.
M. Baron Stanton, of Columbia, for Respondent Phoenix Contract Glass, LLC.
Francis Marion Mack, of Columbia, for Respondent National Grange Mutual Insurance Company.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  The circuit court dismissed EFCO Corporationâ€™s claim for a mechanicâ€™s lien against Renaissance on Charleston Harbor, LLC, and thereafter awarded Renaissance attorney fees and costs pursuant to section 29-5-10(a) of the South Carolina Code.[1]Â  EFCO appeals the award of attorney fees and costs, arguing (1) Renaissance was not a prevailing party as required by the statute and (2) the amount of fees awarded was excessive.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
In August 2001, Renaissance hired a general contractor, Bovis Lend Lease, Inc., to develop a condominium project in Mount Pleasant, South Carolina.Â  Bovis, in turn, hired multiple subcontractors, including Phoenix Contract Glass, LLC, to build various portions of the project.Â  Phoenix purchased supplies and materials from EFCO for the construction of its portion of the project.Â  EFCO is a manufacturer and supplier of architectural windows and framing systems.Â  
On February 4, 2002, EFCO filed a mechanicâ€™s lien (â€œLien Oneâ€) in the amount of $772,841.00 on the condominium property for â€œmaterials and/or labor . . . furnished pursuant to an agreement with PHOENIX CONTRACT GLASS.â€ Â Renaissance â€œbonded offâ€ Lien One by filing a bond with the Charleston County Clerk of Court in April 2002.[3]Â  EFCO did not immediately move to foreclose its lien.Â  Instead, it commenced a debt collection action on Lien One in Richland County on January 8, 2003.Â  
On June 10, 2003, EFCO filed a new mechanicâ€™s lien (â€œLien Twoâ€) in Charleston County for the sum of $793,428.48 as a result of Phoenixâ€™s installation of additional EFCO product in the condominium project during March 2003.Â  This sum allegedly included amounts due under Lien One.Â  EFCO then filed a debt collection action on Lien Two in Charleston County on August 5, 2003 and also moved to foreclose Lien Two.Â  EFCOâ€™s Richland County action was consolidated with this matter.Â  Â Â 
Renaissance filed a motion for summary judgment on October 24, 2003, alleging, among other things, that Lien One should be dissolved because EFCO failed to bring an action to foreclose this lien within six months as required by section 29-5-120 of the South Carolina Code.[4]Â  The circuit court agreed, finding EFCO did not timely file the foreclosure action, and granted Renaissance summary judgment as to Lien One; all other causes of action were allowed to proceed.Â  
Renaissance thereafter filed a motion for attorney fees and costs.Â  The circuit court found Renaissance was the â€œprevailing partyâ€ as required for an award of attorney fees under section 29-5-10(a)[5] and awarded Renaissance attorney fees and costs in the amount of $10,434.00.Â  EFCO appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien is an action at law in South Carolina.[6]Â  â€œIn an
action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence reasonably supporting them.â€[7]Â  â€œThe judgeâ€™s findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.â€[8]Â  Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Prevailing Party
EFCO first argues the circuit court erred in awarding Renaissance attorney fees and costs because Renaissance could not be deemed a â€œprevailing partyâ€ under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.Â  Specifically, EFCO contends (a) Renaissance prevailed in its motion for summary judgment as to Lien One based on a mere technicality, not the merits, and (b) Renaissance might not prevail on the other causes of action that are still pending.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe determination of who is a prevailing party for the purposes of an award of costs is committed to the sound discretion of the trial court.â€[9]Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when a court is controlled by some error of law, or where the order is based upon findings of fact lacking evidentiary support.â€[10]
The general rule in South Carolina is that attorney fees are not recoverable unless they are authorized by contract or by statute.[11]Â  There is no right under the common law to attorney fees.[12]Â  It is undisputed that the mechanicâ€™s lien statute at issue here specifically authorizes the recovery of attorney fees and costs.Â  Section 29-5-10(a) provides in relevant part as follows:Â  

A person to whom a debt is due for labor performed or furnished or for materials furnished and actually used in the erection, alteration, or repair of a building or structure upon real estate . . . shall have a lien upon the building or structure and upon the interest of the owner of the building or structure in the lot of land upon which it is situated to secure the payment of the debt due to him.Â  The costs which may arise in enforcing or defending against the lien under this chapter, including a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee, may be recovered by the prevailing party.[13]

Our supreme court has defined a â€œprevailing partyâ€ as â€œone who successfully prosecutes the action or successfully defends against it, prevailing on the main issue, even though not to the extent of the original contention [and] is the one in whose favor the decision or verdict is rendered and judgment entered.â€[14]Â  â€œ[I]n a mechanicâ€™s lien action the defendant is entitled to an award of attorney fees as the prevailing party if it is determined that a mechanicâ€™s lien cannot be enforced against it.â€[15]Â Â Â  
a.Â  Merits of the Action
The definition of a prevailing party â€œclearly envisions a victory to some degree on the merits.â€[16]Â  â€œWhere the word â€˜meritsâ€™ is used when referring to a case having been decided on the merits, it embraces a consideration of substance, not of form; of legal rights, not of mere defects of procedure or the technicalities thereof.â€[17]Â  
In the current appeal, the circuit court granted summary judgment in favor of Renaissance as to Lien One primarily because EFCO did not bring a foreclosure action within six months of filing its lien as required by statute.Â  â€œStatutes of limitations are not simply technicalities.â€[18]Â  We find Renaissance was a prevailing party because it successfully defended the action based on EFCOâ€™s failure to comply with what, in essence, amounted to a statute of limitations.[19]Â  This finding is in line with prior case law.Â  For example, in Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc. v. Palmieri[20] we held â€œa party may recover attorneyâ€™s fees and costs under Â§ 29-5-20(A)[21] as a â€˜prevailing partyâ€™ even though the party obtained a dismissal via a procedural rule, provided the dismissal was not due to [a] mere technicality.â€[22]Â  
We noted in Keeney that â€œalthough Appellants were dismissed pursuant to a procedural rule, the dismissal was not on a mere technicality.Â  Instead, Appellants prevailed because, as a matter of law, they could not be held liable for the damages Keeney sought under any circumstance.â€[23]Â  Similarly, in the current appeal, Renaissance could not held liable because, as a matter of law, the time for enforcing the lien had already expired.Â  
b.Â  Other Pending Claims 
To the extent EFCO further asserts the circuit court erred in finding Renaissance was a prevailing party because several causes of action are still pending, we find no error.Â  Section 29-5-10(b) of the South Carolina Code provides in relevant part:Â  â€œFor purposes of the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the determination of the prevailing party is based on one verdict in the action.â€[24]Â  Under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, a party who successfully defends a claim for a lien is entitled to recover attorney fees regardless of the outcome of any remaining causes of action.[25]Â  The fees are limited, however, to those actually incurred in defending the lien.[26]Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court did not err in awarding attorney fees to Renaissance relating to its defense of the mechanicâ€™s lien claim.Â  
II.Â  Amount of Attorney Fees Awarded
EFCO next argues that, even if Renaissance was properly deemed a prevailing party, the circuit court abused its discretion in granting attorney fees to Renaissance because the amount of the award was excessive.Â  We disagree.
The determination of the amount of attorney fees that should be awarded under the
mechanicâ€™s lien statute is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court.[27] Â The courtâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an
abuse of discretion.[28]Â  
â€œ[T]he court should consider the following six factors when determining a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee:Â  (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.â€[29]Â  â€œ[O]n appeal, an award for attorneyâ€™s fees will be affirmed so long as sufficient evidence in the record supports each factor.â€[30]Â  
In this case, the circuit court considered each of the requisite factors and the record supports the courtâ€™s findings.Â  Initially, we note Renaissance provided a detailed time sheet outlining the time spent on, and the tasks performed for, this case.Â  We agree with the circuit courtâ€™s determination that the total fee is reasonable in light of the nature of the work performed and the time it took to prepare the case.Â  In addition, Renaissance obtained a beneficial result when the circuit court granted summary judgment to it and dissolved Lien One.Â  Further, the circuit court considered the fees customarily charged in the locality and determined the award was reasonable for defending a lien of approximately $772,841.00 and was related solely to the defense of the mechanicâ€™s lien claim.Â  The remaining factors were not in dispute. Â We therefore find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Renaissance attorney fees and costs in the amount of $10,434.00.
CONCLUSION
Based of the foregoing, we hold Renaissance was the prevailing party under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute and the award of attorney fees and costs in the amount of $10,434.00 was not excessive.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court isÂ  
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â Â Â  

[1] Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (Supp. 2005).Â  
[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-110 (Supp. 2005) (stating a property owner or anyone having an interest in the subject property may secure the discharge of the property from the lien by filing an appropriate bond; the bond then takes the place of the property to secure the lien).Â  Â Â 
[4]Â  Section 29-5-120 provides as follows:Â  â€œUnless a suit for enforcing the lien is commenced, and notice of pendency of the action is filed, within six months after the person desiring to avail himself thereof ceases to labor on or furnish labor or material for such building or structures, the lien shall be dissolved.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-120 (1991) (emphasis added).
[5]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (Supp. 2005).
[6]Â  Adams v. B & D, Inc., 297 S.C. 416, 377 S.E.2d 315 (1989); Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc. v. Palmieri, 345 S.C. 550, 548 S.E.2d 900 (Ct. App. 2001).
[7] Â Adams, 297 S.C. at 420, 377 S.E.2d at 317.Â  
[8] Â Id.
[9]Â  20 Am. Jur. 2d Costs Â§ 11 (2005); see also 20 C.J.S. Costs Â§ 126 (1990).
[10] Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 529, 599 S.E.2d 114, 121 (2004).
[11] Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 427 S.E.2d 659 (1993); Hegler v. Gulf Ins. Co., 270 S.C. 548, 243 S.E.2d 443 (1978).
[12] Prevatte v. Asbury Arms, 302 S.C. 413, 396 S.E.2d 642 (Ct. App. 1990).
[13] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).
[14] Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 182-83, 394 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1990) (alteration in original) (quoting Buza v. Columbia Lumber Co., 395 P.2d 511, 514 (Alaska 1964)); see also Seckinger v. The Vessel Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 483 S.E.2d 775 (Ct. App. 1997) (observing this definition of a prevailing party is applied in the context of statutes allowing attorney fees).
[15] Seckinger, 326 S.C. at 388, 483 S.E.2d at 778; see also Cedar Creek Props. v. Cantelou Assocs., 320 S.C. 483, 486, 465 S.E.2d 774, 776 (Ct. App. 1995) (finding a property owner who filed a complaint to dissolve a mechanicâ€™s lien was the prevailing party where the contractor filed a cancellation of the lien). 
[16] Â Jasper County Bd. of Educ. v. Jasper County Grand Jury, 303 S.C. 49, 52, 398 S.E.2d 498, 500 (1990).
[17] Â 26C Words and Phrases Merits 494 (2003) (referencing Columbia Parcar Corp. v. Arizona Depâ€™t of Transp., 971 P.2d 1042 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1999)); see also id. (â€œAs a technical legal term, â€˜meritsâ€™ has been defined as a matter of substance in law as distinguished from matters of form, and as the real or substantial grounds of action or defense, in contradistinction to some technical or collateral matter raised in the course of the suit.â€ (referencing Wolfe v. Ga. Ry. & Elec. Co., 65 S.E. 62 (Ga. Ct. App. 1909)).
[18] City of North Myrtle Beach v. Lewis-Davis, 360 S.C. 225, 231, 599 S.E.2d 462, 465 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing 54 C.J.S. Limitations of Actions Â§ 2, at 16-17 (1989)).
[19] Cf. Cedar Creek Props., 320 S.C. at 486, 465 S.E.2d at 775-76 (holding a property owner who took affirmative steps to dissolve a contractorâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien was a prevailing party entitled to attorney fees and costs even though the contractor voluntarily cancelled the lien because the contractor did so only after the property owner instituted its action and it still had to defend against the lien until the issue was resolved; the court noted the legislative intent in allowing a prevailing party to recover attorney fees and costs stems from a desire to deter both wrongful filing of liens and unjustified refusal to pay debts subject to mechanicâ€™s liens); 33B Words and Phrases Prevailing Party 242 (2006) (referencing Cedar Creek Props. v. Cantelou Assocs., 320 S.C. 483, 465 S.E.2d 774 (Ct. App. 1995)). 
[20] 345 S.C. 550, 548 S.E.2d 900 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In Keeney the mechanicâ€™s lien could not be enforced because a bond had been executed and, under section 29-5-110, the surety bond took the place of the property upon which the lien existed.Â  Id. at 554-55, 548 S.E.2d at 902.
[21] Although the court in Keeney was analyzing section 29-5-20(A) instead of section 29-5-10(a) as in the present case, both sections provide similar rules for awarding attorney fees to the prevailing party.Â  The only difference in the two sections is that the former concerns liens filed by subcontractors and suppliers, whereas the latter addresses liens filed by persons furnishing labor and materials and also addresses settlements to enforce liens.
[22] Id. at 556, 548 S.E.2d at 903.
[23] Id. at 555, 548 S.E.2d at 902-03.

App. 1996) (upholding an award of attorney fees to a property owner who successfully defended a contractorâ€™s claim for a mechanicâ€™s lien, even though the owner lost on the contractorâ€™s claims for unjust enrichment and breach of contract; we noted the trial court had directed a verdict on the mechanicâ€™s lien to the owner and, under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, a party is entitled to recover attorney fees if the party prevails in defending the lien); 33B Words and Phrases Prevailing Party 242 (2006) (stating a â€œ[p]arty need not be successful as to all issues in order to be found to be a â€˜prevailing partyâ€™ for purposes of [an] attorney fee awardâ€ (referencing Seckinger v. The Vessel Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 483 S.E.2d 775 (Ct. App. 1997))).

Costs Â§ 126 (1990) (â€œWhere a party is successful on some claims but not others, he may be considered a prevailing party, but is entitled to an award only for fees generated in connection with the successful claims . . . .â€ (footnote omitted)).
[27] Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc., 345 S.C. at 553, 548 S.E.2d at 901. 
[28] Id.; see also Zepsa Constr., Inc v. Randazzo, 357 S.C. 32, 40, 591 S.E.2d 29, 33 (Ct. App. 2004); 56 C.J.S. Mechanicsâ€™ Liens Â§ 436 (1992).
[29] Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 308, 486 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1997) (citing Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 427 S.E.2d 659 (1993)).

title: State v. Rikard
description: Appellant appeals her plea of guilty to felony driving under the influence causing death and felony driving under the influence causing great bodily injury.  She asserts the circuit court judge erred in refusing to allow her to withdraw her guilty plea.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Dana Rae Rikard, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4156
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 2, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen Drew Geoly, of Greenwood, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Dana Rae Rikard appeals her plea of guilty to felony driving under the influence causing death and felony driving under the influence causing great bodily injury.Â  She asserts the circuit court judge erred in refusing to allow her to withdraw her guilty plea.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
After spending the afternoon and evening at the I-20 Speedway in Pelion on April 6, 2002, Rikard drove home with her four-year-old daughter at approximately 11:15 p.m.Â  While driving down US-178, Rikard collided with an on-coming vehicle driven by Stephanie Braithwaite.Â  Rikardâ€™s daughter, who was not restrained by a seatbelt or a car seat, died at the scene after she was ejected from the vehicle.Â  Braithwaiteâ€™s four-year-old son was rendered unconscious as a result of the impact.Â  Braithwaite, with the assistance of a passerby, was able to extricate her son from the vehicle before it caught fire.Â  Braithwaiteâ€™s son was immediately airlifted to Palmetto Richland Hospital where he spent several days to be treated for a subdural hematoma and a broken femur. 
While investigating the accident, the officers called to the scene searched Rikardâ€™s vehicle.Â  During this search, the officers observed the speedometer was â€œlockedâ€ around eighty miles per hour and found several empty bottles of Zima.Â  According to the officers, Rikard admitted drinking eight Zimas prior to the accident.Â  Three hours after the accident, Rikardâ€™s blood was tested at the hospital.Â  Toxicology reports revealed Rikardâ€™s blood alcohol content was .11.Â  As part of the SLED investigation, the toxicologist opined that Rikardâ€™s blood alcohol content would have been approximately .173 at the time of the accident.
On November 1, 2004, a Lexington County grand jury indicted Rikard for the following offenses:Â  child endangerment, open container violation, violation of the child restraint law, a seatbelt violation, felony driving under the influence (DUI) causing great bodily injury, and felony DUI causing death.Â  
On April 4, 2005, Rikard pleaded guilty to the felony DUI charges.[2]Â  Â Â During the plea colloquy, the circuit court judge inquired about Rikardâ€™s education level, marital status, and employment history.Â  As to the specific charges, the judge informed Rikard that her plea would be a â€œstraight-upâ€ plea without any recommendations or negotiated sentence from the State.Â  He further informed her of the maximum possible sentence for each offense and the constitutional rights she was waiving by pleading guilty.Â  Upon hearing the judgeâ€™s instructions, Rikard admitted she was guilty of the charged offenses and indicated that she wanted to plead guilty.Â  Â Â 
After determining that Rikardâ€™s guilty plea was freely and voluntarily given, the judge permitted the solicitor to give a recitation of the facts.Â  At the conclusion of this presentation, the solicitor stated, â€œwe would ask for the maximum sentence allowed under the law in this case.â€ Â The judge accepted Rikardâ€™s guilty plea after hearing the factual basis for the plea. 
In mitigation, Rikardâ€™s counsel stated that Rikard was remorseful and that she had two children who needed her at home.Â  Counsel claimed Rikardâ€™s husband, from whom she was separated, was not notified in time to attend the plea proceeding.Â  Counsel further challenged points in the accident investigation, specifically the alleged speed of Rikardâ€™s vehicle before the collision.Â  Additionally, counsel stated that Rikard did not believe she was under the influence at the time of the accident even though she admitted to drinking some alcohol that night. Â He requested the court â€œbe as merciful as possible in this case.â€
After hearing from Rikard and her mother, the judge sentenced Rikard to twenty-two years imprisonment and a $10,000 fine for felony DUI causing death and fifteen years imprisonment and a $5,000 fine for felony DUI causing great bodily injury.Â  The sentences were to be served concurrently.Â  
Subsequently, Rikard filed a motion to withdraw her plea, or in the alternative, a motion to reconsider the sentence.Â  In this motion, Rikardâ€™s counsel alleged prejudicial misconduct on the part of the State. Â Counsel submitted affidavits and letters from Rikardâ€™s family in support of this assertion. 
In terms of the alleged misconduct, Rikard claimed the State acted improperly before and during the plea hearing.Â  Specifically, Rikardâ€™s counsel contended the State failed to disclose during discovery:Â  (1) that there was evidence Rikardâ€™s blood alcohol content was .173; (2) photographs of the scene depicting the deceased child; and (3) Rikardâ€™s alleged admissions regarding her consumption of alcohol prior to the accident.Â  Additionally, counsel claimed the State failed to notify Rikardâ€™s husband and her two other children of the hearing pursuant to the Victimâ€™s Bill of Rights.[3]Â  Rikard believed her family members could have offered evidence in mitigation.Â  
With respect to the Stateâ€™s actions during the hearing, Rikardâ€™s counsel asserted the solicitorâ€™s representation of the facts, particularly the description of the deceased childâ€™s final moments after the accident and the cause of the accident, was exaggerated and rose to the level of misrepresentation.Â  Counsel contended Rikard did not agree with this recitation of the facts. Rikardâ€™s counsel further argued the State failed to honor its representation that it would not make a recommendation regarding sentencing when the solicitor requested the maximum sentence during the hearing.Â  
After a hearing, the circuit court judge denied Rikardâ€™s motion to withdraw her plea as well as the motion to reconsider the sentence.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
Rikard argues the circuit court judge erred in accepting her plea or refusing to allow her to withdraw her plea on the grounds:Â  (1) she did not admit to the facts presented by the State; and (2) the State indicated on the sentencing sheet that it would make no recommendation regarding her sentence but then, during the plea hearing, requested the court impose the maximum sentence.Â  We disagree.
A trial judge should not accept a guilty plea without an affirmative showing that it was intelligent and voluntary.Â  Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238, 241 (1969).Â  Additionally, to knowingly and voluntarily enter a plea of guilty, all that is required is that a defendant has a full understanding of the consequences of her plea and the charges against her.Â  Simpson v. State, 317 S.C. 506, 508, 455 S.E.2d 175, 176 (1995).Â  Moreover, the record in a guilty plea proceeding must establish a factual basis for the plea.Â  LoPiano v. State, 270 S.C. 563, 569, 243 S.E.2d 448, 451 (1978); State v. Armstrong, 263 S.C. 594, 598, 211 S.E.2d 889, 891 (1975).Â  In accepting a guilty plea, â€œthe trial judge is free to use any appropriate procedure for determining the accuracy of the guilty plea.Â  The judge must be certain that the defendant understands the charge and the consequences of the plea and that the record indicates a factual basis for the plea.â€Â  Armstrong, 263 S.C. at 598, 211 S.E.2d at 891. Â â€œAll that is required before a plea can be accepted is that the defendant understand the nature and crucial elements of the charges, the consequences of the plea, and the constitutional rights he is waiving, and that the record reflect a factual basis for the plea.â€Â 
Rollison v. State, 346 S.C. 506, 511, 552 S.E.2d 290, 292 (2001).
â€œThe withdrawal of a guilty plea is generally within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  State v. Riddle, 278 S.C. 148, 150, 292 S.E.2d 795, 796 (1982).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial judgeâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Lopez, 352 S.C. 373, 378, 574 S.E.2d 210, 212 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  A determination the plea was voluntarily entered â€œwill normally show the trial judge did not abuse his discretion.â€Â  Riddle, 278 S.C. at 150, 292 S.E.2d at 796; see State v. Cantrell, 250 S.C. 376, 378, 158 S.E.2d 189, 191 (1967)(â€œA motion to withdraw a plea of guilty, and to be allowed to enter a plea of not guilty, addresses itself to the discretion of the trial judge before whom the plea is entered, and, in the absence of a clear abuse of discretion, this court will not interfere.â€).
Although we will separately address each of Rikardâ€™s contentions, we find the circuit court judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Rikardâ€™s motion to withdraw her plea.Â  
In terms of the factual basis for the plea, the judge properly allowed the solicitor to give a recitation of the facts on the record.Â  Even though Rikard did not specifically acknowledge the accuracy of the Stateâ€™s factual presentation, she did not raise any objection at the hearing and, through her counsel, had the opportunity to challenge certain aspects of the Stateâ€™s factual presentation.Â  Moreover, during the plea colloquy Rikard admitted she was guilty of the charged offenses for which she had been apprised of the elements.Â  Because the solicitor provided a sufficient factual basis in the record to support each of the DUI charges, we find Rikardâ€™s argument to be without merit.
Next, we turn to Rikardâ€™s allegation that the State failed to abide by its representation on the sentencing sheet not to recommend a sentence.Â  Rikard contends she was induced to plead guilty and would not have but for the Stateâ€™s representation that it would not recommend any particular sentence.Â  Initially, we note Rikard concedes in her brief that the sentencing sheet did not constitute a formal plea agreement. Â Thus, we do not believe the same stringent requirements of plea agreements would apply to the instant case.Â  However, even if we construe the sentencing sheet as rising to the level of a contractual obligation, we find the judge did not err in declining to allow Rikard to withdraw her plea.Â  See Sprouse v. State, 355 S.C. 335, 338, 585 S.E.2d 278, 279 (2003)(â€œ[S]tate prosecutors are obligated to fulfill the promises they make to defendants when those promises serve as inducements to defendants to plead guilty.â€ (citing Santobello v. New York, 404 U.S. 257 (1971))); State v. Thomason, 355 S.C. 278, 286, 584 S.E.2d 143, 147 (Ct. App. 2003)(â€œOur supreme court has recognized a plea agreement rests on contractual principles.â€).
Rikardâ€™s reliance on the sentencing sheet is unavailing.Â  The sentencing sheet offers three alternatives to designate the nature or status of the plea.Â  Those alternatives provide that the plea is:Â  (1) without negotiations or recommendation; (2) a negotiated sentence; or (3) a recommendation by the State.Â  In this instance, the option of â€œwithout negotiations or recommendationâ€ was selected by the solicitor, Rikard, and Rikardâ€™s counsel.Â  It is axiomatic that the phrase â€œwithout negotiations or recommendationâ€ means that the State and the defendant have not agreed on sentencing.Â  Therefore, either party is free to request a favorable sentence.
During the plea colloquy Rikard acknowledged to the judge that she understood the charges, the maximum possible sentences, and that her plea was a â€œstraight-upâ€ plea without any negotiations or recommendations.Â  Taking all of these considerations into account, the judge ultimately determined Rikard was freely and voluntarily pleading guilty.Â  Finally, the judge exercised discretion when he declined to impose the maximum sentence on each charge and ordered the sentences to be served concurrently.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2945(A)(1), (2) (Supp.Â  2005) (establishing maximum term of imprisonment for felony DUI when death results as twenty-five years imprisonment and fifteen years for felony DUI causing great bodily injury); Brooks v. State, 325 S.C. 269, 271, 481 S.E.2d 712, 713 (1997)(â€œA trial judge is allowed broad discretion in sentencing within statutory limits.â€).Â  Thus, we find no error in the judgeâ€™s decision accepting Rikardâ€™s plea and refusing her request to withdraw her plea.[4]Â  See State v. Barton, 325 S.C. 522, 531, 481 S.E.2d 439, 444 (Ct. App. 1997) (finding no error in trial judgeâ€™s refusal to allow appellant to withdraw guilty plea where appellant failed to object at any point before the judge accepted his guilty plea and judge:Â  considered evidence presented by appellant, allowed appellant to testify about the nature of the guilty plea, and thoroughly questioned appellant during guilty plea).
Accordingly, Rikardâ€™s guilty plea and sentence are
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â Â  The solicitor dismissed the collateral traffic violations as a result of the plea. 
[3]Â Â  S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 24.
[4]Â Â  In support of her argument, Rikard relies on our supreme courtâ€™s decision in Jordan v. State, 297 S.C. 52, 374 S.E.2d 683 (1988).Â  We find this case to be distinguishable from the instant case.Â  In Jordan, appellant petitioned for post-conviction relief on the ground his counsel was ineffective for failing to withdraw appellantâ€™s guilty plea after the State reneged on a plea bargain.Â  According to appellant, he only agreed to plead guilty when the assistant solicitor indicated the State would neither recommend nor oppose a probationary sentence for the charge of assault and battery with a deadly weapon.Â  At the guilty plea hearing, another assistant solicitor appeared for the State and opposed a probationary sentence.Â  Appellantâ€™s counsel did not request to withdraw the plea or point out to the judge that the State had changed the plea agreement.Â  The trial judge declined to reconsider his sentence because he was not influenced by the assistant solicitorâ€™s opposition to probation.Â  Our supreme court vacated appellantâ€™s sentence and remanded for either specific performance of the plea agreement and resentencing or for a new trial.Â  The court found appellantâ€™s counsel erred in failing to protect appellantâ€™s right to enforce the plea agreement.Â Â  Here, unlike in Jordan, the State did not promise anything in exchange for Rikardâ€™s plea.Â  Rikard also acknowledged during the plea hearing that it was a â€œstraight-upâ€ plea without any negotiations.Â

title: Sanders v. MeadWestvaco Corporation
description: In this workers' compensation action, MeadWestvaco Corporation appeals the circuit cout's order affirming teh Appellate Panel of the Workers' Compensation Commission awarding Kenneth Sanders permanent partial disability to his lumbar spine and sacroiliac joint (SI joint).  MeadWestvaco also appeal the circuit court's failure to find it was entitled to credit for overpayment of temporary total disability from the date Sanders reached maximum medical improvement.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kenneth W. Sanders, Respondent,
v.
MeadWestvaco Corporation, Self-Insured Employer,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4157
Heard June 14, 2006 â€“ Filed October 2, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Kirsten Leslie Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
Ben C. Harrison, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, MeadWestvaco Corporation (Westvaco) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the Â Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Appellate Panel) awarding Â Kenneth Sanders (Sanders) a 40% permanent partial disability Â to his lumbar spine and sacroiliac joint (SI joint).Â  Westvaco also appeals the circuit courtâ€™s failure to find it was entitled to credit for overpayment of temporary total disability from the date Sanders reached maximum medical improvement.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
Sanders, a chip mill operator employed by Westvaco, was injured on March 16, 2001, when a front-end loader flung a piece of wood that struck Sanders in his knee. Â Sanders was taken immediately to the emergency room where he was treated for the injury. Â 
Several months later Sanders began to complain about lower back pain that radiated into his right hip and buttock region. Â On August 27, 2001, Dr. Phillip Milner noted that Sanders was having a â€œpalpable snapâ€ of the right SI joint, occurring repetitively when he turned his leg or lifted his leg, which he described as a â€œvery consistent and a noticeable finding.â€ After an MRI scan showed a herniated disc at L4/5 with right L5 root involvement, Dr. Milner referred Sanders to Dr. Charles Hughes for an epidural injection.Â  
Dr. Hughes attempted to treat Sandersâ€™ herniated disc with several epidural steroid injections, followed by a right SI joint block injection procedure.Â  He believed, as did Dr. Jacquelyn Van Dam, who was consulted to perform an EMG study, that the herniated disc was not a reasonable source of Sandersâ€™ back pain and that surgery would not benefit him. When conservative treatment failed to make a notable difference, Dr. Hughes referred Sanders to Dr. William Felmly at the Moore Orthopedic Clinic for another surgical opinion.Â  Â 
After meeting with Sanders on a single occasion, Dr. Felmly concluded Sanders had a chronic SI joint problem but surgery was not warranted. Dr. Felmly opined Sanders had a 2% permanent partial impairment of the SI joint.Â  After reviewing Dr. Felmlyâ€™s report, Dr. Hughes found Sanders had reached maximum medical improvement (MMI) and had a 12% impairment of the SI joint and a whole person impairment of 2%. Â Further, Dr. Hughes believed, as did Dr. Felmly, that Sanders was limited by his own subjective complaints. 
Sanders then saw Dr. Samuel Seastrunk.Â  After an independent medical evaluation of Sanders, Dr. Seastrunk stated Sanders had: (1) an L4/5 disc herniation with significant involvement of the L5 nerve root and radiculitis, and (2) a complex problem with SI instability. Dr. Seastrunk, in sharp contrast with previous doctors, rated the impairment of the lumbar spine at 18%, and an impairment of 22% to the whole person. Â 
On September 26, 2002, Westvaco filed a Form 21 Hearing Request seeking to stop payment of temporary total disability benefits. Â Moreover, Westvaco sought a credit for any overpayment beyond Sandersâ€™ date of MMI, which both parties stipulated occurred on August 21, 2002.Â  Also, Westvaco questioned the compensability of Sandersâ€™ claim of anxiety and depression as well as the extent of his disability.Â  Sanders contended he was permanently and totally disabled and sought additional medical care. Â 
After a hearing, the single commissioner concluded Sanders did not meet his burden of proving his depression and anxiety were causally related to his work-related injury. Â The single commissioner also found that Sanders had a 13% loss of use of his right leg due to the accident.Â  Further, the single commissioner found:

After considering the opinion of Dr. Seastrunk and his impairment rating of 22%, and after considering the opinions of Dr. Hughes, Dr. VanDam, and Dr. Felmly suggesting that the Claimantâ€™s subjective complaints are out of proportion with his objective physical findings . . . and after considering the opinions [of all of the doctors] indicating that the Claimant did not need surgery or other invasive treatment as a result of the March 16, 2001 accident; and notwithstanding the Dr. Hughesâ€™s and Dr. Felmlyâ€™s opinion that Claimant sustained only a 2% impairment, I find that the Claimant is credible and has a 40% loss of use of his lumbar spine and SI Joint as a result of chronic pain and a potential need for surgery to these areas. 

Accordingly, the single commissioner found Sanders was entitled to future medical treatment â€œfor medication, pain management, his TENS unit, and SI beltâ€ to lessen his period of disability.Â  The single commissioner granted Westvacoâ€™s request to terminate temporary total disability compensation but found Westvaco was only entitled to a credit for overpayment for the period after January 16, 2003, which was the day before the hearing.
The Appellate Panel affirmed the single commissioner, adopting the single commissionerâ€™s findings in full. Â Following a hearing on the matter, the circuit court affirmed the decision of the Appellate Panel, finding the decision was supported by substantial evidence in the record and that Sandersâ€™ testimony alone provided substantial evidence to support the finding that he had 40% loss of use of his back.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the Appellate Panel.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  The Appellate Panel is specifically reserved the task of assessing the credibility of the witnesses and the weight to be accorded evidence.Â  Id.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
On appeal from the Appellate Panel, this court may reverse or modify a decision if the findings or conclusions of the Appellate Panel are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  This court cannot substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  A finding is supported by substantial evidence â€œunless there is no reasonable probability that the facts could be as related by a witness upon whose testimony the finding was based.â€Â  Lark, 276 S.C. at 136, 276 S.E.2d at 307.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Section 42-9-30 Analysis
On appeal, Westvaco first argues that section 42-9-30 of the South Carolina Code (1985) permits disability awards based on degrees of medical impairment to Â­Â­specified body parts, and the circuit court erred in affirming an award of benefits based upon impairment to functional units of the back, i.e., the lumbar spine and SI joint which are not scheduled for compensation under section 42-9-30.Â  We disagree.
The Appellate Panel concluded Sanders was entitled to compensation under section 42-9-30 (19) for â€œpermanent loss of use of the lumbar spine and SI joint.â€ Section 42-9-30(19) provides for compensation for injury to the back as follows:

For the total loss of use of the back, sixty-six and two-thirds percent of the average weekly wages during three hundred weeks. The compensation for partial loss of use of the back shall be such proportions of the periods of payment herein provided for total loss as such partial loss bear to total loss . . . . 

In affirming the Appellate Panel, the circuit court interpreted the Appellate Panelâ€™s order to have awarded benefits based on injuries to the back. The circuit court concluded â€œ[a] review of the record reflects that these injuries and disabilities were clearly to the back.â€Â Â  Westvacoâ€™s argument that because the Appellate Panelâ€™s order was too specific in identifying the regions of the back where Sandersâ€™ loss of use occurred and that these regions are somehow separate from the back itself is without merit. 
Accordingly, even though the SI joint and lumbar spine are not specifically mentioned in section 42-9-30, we find no reversible error in the manner in which the Appellate Panel characterized Sandersâ€™ injuries.[1] Â A review of the Appellate Panelâ€™s order and the record reflects Sandersâ€™ injury and subsequent disability was clearly to his back.Â  This approach is consistent with our policy of
liberally construing the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act in favor of coverage.Â  Schulknight v. City of N. Charleston, 352 S.C. 175, 178, 574 S.E.2d 194, 195 (2002); see also Mgmt. Recruiters v. R.J.R. Mech., Inc., 304 S.C. 399, 401, 404 S.E.2d 908, 909 (Ct. App. 1991) (finding when construing a judgment, the determinative factor is the â€œintent of the officer who wrote it, as gathered not from an isolated part of the judgment, but from all parts thereofâ€). Â 
II. Impairment Rating
Next, Westvaco argues the evidence was insufficient to establish Sanders suffered a 40% loss of use of his back.Â  Westvacoâ€™s contentions are twofold: (1) the medical testimony established, at most, a 22% impairment rating; and (2) the circuit court erred in affirming an award based upon the potential need for future surgery.Â  
A.  Evidence of Impairment 
Westvaco argues Sanders is not entitled to benefits because the evidence was insufficient to establish he suffered a 40% loss of use of his back.Â  Westvaco contends only the opinion of medical experts can be used to assess Sandersâ€™ impairment.Â  We disagree.
Westvaco argues that since Sanders was awarded disability under Â§ 42-9-30, Wigfall v. Tideland Util., Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 580 S.E.2d 100 (2003), should be controlling regarding the impairment rating.Â  After reviewing the Wigfall courtâ€™s decision, we agree that this case falls within the Wigfall medical model encompassed in Â§ 42-9-30. 354 S.C. at 107, 580 S.E.2d at 103. We do not agree that a determination of impairment under this section mandates that only medical evidence may be considered by the Commission in determining the degree of disability.
While an impairment rating may not rest on â€œsurmise, speculation or conjecture . . . Â it is not necessary that the percentage of disability or loss of use be shown with mathematical exactness.â€Â  Roper v. Kimbrellâ€™s of Greenville, 231 S.C. 453, 461, 99 S.E.2d 52, 57 (1957) (citations omitted); see also Linen v. Ruscon Constr. Co., 286 S.C. 67, 68-69, 332 S.E.2d 211, 212 (1985) (finding that although expert testimony found claimant suffered from a 20-30% impairment to his back, testimony of vocational expert and claimant provided substantial evidence to affirm Appellate Panelâ€™s decision finding claimantâ€™s impairment exceeded 50%); Lyles v. Quantum Chem. Co, 315 S.C. 440, 445-46, 434 S.E.2d 292, 294-95 (Ct. App. 1993) (finding, pursuant to section 42-9-30, that while expert testimony suggested claimant suffered only a 35% impairment to his back, testimony of claimant and others provided substantial evidence that claimantâ€™s impairment exceeded 50%).Â  
Further, the Appellate Panel is not bound by the opinion of medical experts and â€œmay find a degree of disability different from that suggested by expert testimony.â€Â  Lyles, 315 at 445, 434 S.E.2d at 295 (citations omitted).Â  Expert medical testimony is merely intended to aid the Appellate Panel in coming to the correct conclusion.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 624, 571 S.E.2d 92, 98 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 513 S.E.2d 843 (1999)).Â  â€œUnless the question of the extent of partial loss of use under [section] 42-9-30 is so technically complicated as to require exclusively expert testimony, lay testimony is admissible.â€Â  Linen, 286 S.C. at 68, 332 S.E.2d at 212.
Although Dr. Seastrunk found Sandersâ€™ impairment was at 22% to the whole person, Sanders testified at length to the character and extent of his back injury and the restrictions the injury has placed on his physical activities.Â  Sanders testified he has pain in the lower back shooting down into his right buttock and into his leg stopping just above his knee.Â  He utilizes a TENS unit for pain as well as a sacroiliac belt that he wears daily.Â  He has trouble sitting because he must constantly change positions to keep weight off his right buttock.Â  He takes pain medication in order to walk normally.Â  His pain affects his sleeping, allowing him to sleep only five hours a night.Â  He can no longer walk up the steps in the front of his house and now must enter through the back.Â  Sanders testified he used to play tennis three times a week and enjoyed fishing, hunting, and horseback riding.Â  He even built his own home.Â  He testified since his work-related accident, he is no longer an active person and cannot even tie his own shoes.Â  Â Â Â 
Although some of the medical evidence may suggest Sanders is not impaired by his back injury, â€œit is not for this court to balance objective against subjective findings of medical witnesses, or to weigh the testimony of one witness against that of another.â€Â  Roper, 231 S.C. at 461, 99 S.E.2d at 57.Â  That function belongs to the Appellate Panel alone.Â  Id.Â  Further, the Appellate Panel correctly considered both medical and lay testimony in arriving at its decision.Â  See Linen, 286 S.C. at 68, 332 S.E.2d at 212. Â Â Â 
A review of the Appellate Panelâ€™s order reveals it considered, in detail, all expert and lay testimony before making its ruling.Â  Important to the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision was Sandersâ€™ testimony, which the Appellate Panel found credible.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s consideration of both lay and medical testimony in arriving at its decision.Â Â  
B.  Award Based on Potential Need for Surgery Â  
Although we agree with Sanders that the Appellate Panel may utilize lay testimony to reach an impairment rating higher than that testified to by the medical experts, we find that the Appellate Panel erred as a matter of law in basing its award of a 40% impairment of the back on a potential need for surgery. 
As we stated in Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 467, 622 S.E.2d 577, 585 (Ct. App. 2005), â€œ[m]aximum medical improvement is a term used to indicate that a person has reached such a plateau that in the physicianâ€™s opinion there is no further medical care or treatment which will lessen the degree of impairment.â€ (citations omitted).Â  However, the fact that a claimant has reached MMI does not necessarily preclude a finding that additional medical treatment may be needed if the medical treatment would tend to improve the claimantâ€™s quality of life but not further improve the medical condition.Â  See Pearson v. JPS Converter & Indus. Corp., 327 S.C. 393, 398, 489 S.E.2d 219, 221 (Ct. App. 1997) (citing Oâ€™Banner v. Westinghouse Elec. Corp., 319 S.C. 24, 459 S.E.2d 324 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œContinued treatment of prescriptive medicine did not preclude a finding of maximum medical improvement, because the medication could temporarily alleviate claimantâ€™s symptoms but not further improve his medical condition.â€).Â  
In the instant case, the parties stipulated Sanders reached MMI on August 21, 2002, and as such was entitled to future medical care that would tend to alleviate his symptoms but not further improve his medical condition.Â  Moreover, Westvaco has not appealed the Appellate Panel awarding Sanders future treatment for pain as future medical care. Â However, the Appellate Panel incorrectly premised its award of 40% loss of use of the back on a potential need for surgery.Â  Sanders has not pointed to any case law, statute or regulation that would allow the Appellate Panel to base an impairment rating under section 42-9-30 upon a potential need for surgery, where no evidence suggests that the surgery would be needed to alleviate Sandersâ€™ symptoms as opposed to further improving his medical condition.Â  Accordingly, we reverse and remand to the Appellate Panel to determine how much of its award was based upon its conclusion that Sanders may need surgery in the future and to recalculate, if appropriate, Sandersâ€™ degree of impairment.Â  Â Â 
III.  Overpayment of Temporary Total Benefits
Westvaco argues the Appellate Panel erred in limiting its credit for overpayment to the period commencing the day preceding the hearing before the single commissioner. Â We agree.Â  Â 
Credit for overpayment of temporary total benefits is governed by section 42-9-210 (1985) of the South Carolina Code:

Any payments made by an employer to an injured employee during the period of his disability, or to his dependents, which by the terms of this Title were not due and payable when made may, subject to the approval of the Commission, be deducted from the amount to be paid as compensation; provided, that in the case of disability such deductions shall be made by shortening the period during which compensation must be paid and not by reducing the amount of the weekly payment.

In the case of Hendricks v. Pickens County, 335 S.C. 405, 414, 517 S.E.2d 698, 703 (Ct. App. 1999), we held that â€œ[o]nce the [Appellate Panel] affirmed that (employee) had reached MMI, it was then appropriate to terminate TTD benefits in favor of either permanent partial or permanent total disability benefits, if warranted by substantial evidence in the record.â€Â  (citations omitted).Â  See also Smith v. S.C. Dept. of Mental Health, 335 S.C. 396, 399, 517 S.E.2d 694, 696 (1999) (â€œThe rationale for ceasing temporary benefits upon a finding of MMI is to permit entry of a permanent award.Â  Clearly, if an employee has reached MMI and remains disabled, then his injury is permanent . . . This is precisely the reason to terminate temporary benefits in favor of permanent benefits upon a finding of MMI.â€). 
It is undisputed MMI was reached on August 21, 2002, and the hearing before the single commissioner was on January 16, 2003.Â  The Appellate Panel found that due to the fact the hearing was rescheduled â€œseveral times,â€ Westvaco was only entitled to credit for overpayments for the period after January 16, 2003. Â The Respondent admitted at oral argument that the hearing had been rescheduled twice, once at the request of the employer, and once at the request of Sanders. Â Under section 42-9-260, Westvaco was entitled to have its request to terminate temporary total benefits heard within 60 days of filing the request. Â Here, the delay in having a timely hearing falls squarely on both parties. Â Thus, we find no substantial evidence supporting the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision to overpay benefits to Sanders.Â  Therefore, we remand this issue to the Appellate Panel for a determination as to the appropriate date for crediting Westvaco with overpayments.
CONCLUSION
The decision of the circuit court affirming the Appellate Panel is reversed and this case is remanded to the Appellate Panel for a determination of the degree of impairment Sanders suffered to his back as a result of his injury on March 16, 2001. Â We also remand for a determination of the appropriate periodÂ  Westvaco should receive credit for the overpayment of temporary total benefits.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

[1] We note the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding of impairment to the lumbar spine and SI Joint is premised on Dr. Seastrunkâ€™s impairment rating of 22% to the back which can be equated to the whole person.Â  At oral argument, both Sanders and Westvaco agreed the whole person and the whole back are equivalent in terms of disability under the AMA Guidelines.Â  Stated differently, both agreed that impairment to the whole back is equal to impairment of the whole person.Â

title: LaFrance v. LaFrance
description: In this domestic action, Michael Leo LaFrance (â€œHusbandâ€) appeals the family courtâ€™s imputation of income, division of marital assets, calculation of child support, and award of attorneyâ€™s fees.  Claire Elizabeth Mouton LaFrance (â€œWifeâ€) cross appeals the family courtâ€™s awarding Husband a share in the future profits from the sale of the marital home, classifying Wifeâ€™s jewelry as marital property, and issuing the Supplemental Order dated September 29, 2004 that required each party to share guardian ad litem fees.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Claire Elizabeth Mouton LaFrance, Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Michael Leo LaFrance, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Stephen S. Bartlett, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4158
Heard September 12, 2006 â€“ Filed October 2, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED


  
    
      
J. Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant/Respondent.
Timothy E. Madden, of Greenville, for Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â In this domestic action, Michael Leo LaFrance (â€œHusbandâ€) appeals the family courtâ€™s imputation of income, division of marital assets, calculation of child support, and award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Claire Elizabeth Mouton LaFrance (â€œWifeâ€) cross appeals the family courtâ€™s awarding Husband a share in the future profits from the sale of the marital home, classifying Wifeâ€™s jewelry as marital property, and issuing the Supplemental Order dated September 29, 2004 that required each party to share guardian ad litem fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife married in 1989 and had three children, who at the time of the final hearing were eight, five and four years old. During their fourteen-year marriage the parties relocated a number of times to pursue Husbandâ€™s professional opportunities and to improve the partiesâ€™ financial position. 
In Lafayette, Louisiana, where the parties married, both worked for Comtel, a telecommunications company.Â  Wife was employed as a sales representative and Husband was a senior executive.Â  Her salary at the time was approximately $45,000.00 and Husbandâ€™s was approximately $75,000.00.Â  
Comtel merged in 1990 with a long distance telecommunications company, and the couple relocated to Jackson, Mississippi. Â Husbandâ€™s salary at that time was approximately $80,000.00, plus stock options.Â  Wife completed her college education during that time and, in addition, worked in a local boutique. 
Early in the 1990s Husband started a wireless paging company in Covington, Louisiana.Â  He earned approximately $40,000 per year in this two-year venture.Â  Wife started a bridal registry business, which, though allegedly successful, did not result in any personal income because she put all profits back into the business. 
In 1993 or 1994, the couple relocated to Rochester, New York, where Husband accepted an executive level management position with ACC Communications at an initial salary of approximately $150,000.00, plus stock options.Â  Wife returned to work for a short time until the parties decided to buy a home and start a family.Â  Both agreed Wife would not work outside the home.Â  
In 1997 Husband left ACC, having acquired approximately four million dollars in assets generated by his stocks and options.Â  The family moved to Greenville, South Carolina, where Husband entered a start-up telecommunications venture, â€œNew South,â€ and assumed the position of Chief Executive Officer (CEO).Â  His initial annual salary was $70,000.00, plus stock options.Â  When Husband was terminated from New South in 2001, his annual salary was $150,000.00, plus bonuses and stock options. 
At the time of the final hearing in March of 2004, both parties resided in Greenville, South Carolina.Â  Wife was thirty-eight years old and Husband was forty-three.Â  Both graduated from college.Â  Wife takes prescription medication for anxiety but claimed to be in good health otherwise.Â  Husband has severe back problems, has had surgery, and continues to suffer chronic pain.Â  Associated with Husbandâ€™s back injury is a history of addiction to pain medication, for which he has received some rehabilitative treatment.Â  Husband has not been employed since his termination from New South.Â  Â Wife began working in the spring of 2003 as a Physicianâ€™s Liaison with the Greenville Hospital System, earning approximately $75,000.00 annually. 
On February 25, 2002, Wife petitioned for divorce on the ground of continuously living separate and apart for one year without intervening cohabitation. Subsequently, Husband and Wife agreed upon custody, visitation, family support, and division of certain marital assets.[1]  
The parties had significant marital property, which, in addition to the marital home, included cash, checking accounts, retirement assets, investment accounts and securities, insurance policies and proceeds, potential income tax refunds and substantial personal property in the form of antiques, home furnishings, vehicles, firearms, coin collections, childrenâ€™s portraits, jewelry, and gold coins. 
At the commencement of trial Wife withdrew her requests 1) for permanent alimony; and 2) that Husband maintain a life insurance policy as an incident of support.Â  Instead, Wife sought equitable apportionment of the policy as one of the marital assets.Â  The issues before the court for disposition on final hearing included: divorce; identification, valuation and apportionment of marital assets and marital debts; child support; modification of prior support orders; and attorneyâ€™s fees. 
The family court awarded Wife a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation without intervening cohabitation.Â  The parties stipulated that Wife maintain custody of the three minor children, allowing Husband reasonable visitation.Â  The litigants agreed to the permanent apportionment of New South interests in percentages consistent with the apportionment of the general marital estate.Â  Stipulations of the parties were adopted, incorporated into and merged with the final decree and order.Â  The family court identified, valued and equitably apportioned the partiesâ€™ marital property and debts. The final order provided:

   Among the marital assets is the marital home . . . . [T]he greater and more credible evidence supports a fair market valuation of $700,000.00 . . . . The marital home is subject to mortgage indebtedness which has a date of filing balance due of $404,000.00 . . . .
    [A]fter considering this indebtedness, the net fair market value of the equity in this home is $296,000.00.
  [I]n the event the marital home is sold within six years of this Order, and the sales price exceeds $700,000.00, any excess net proceeds (resulting from a sales price over $700,000.00) shall be distributed equally to the parties, provided, that any increase in the value of the house that is the direct result of Wifeâ€™s direct contribution or improvement to the house subsequent to this Order shall not be subject to distribution.Â  This Court reserves jurisdiction to determine the extent of direct contributions in the event that the marital home sells within the six-year period.
   Without question or contest, Husband made the vast majority of the direct contributions to the marriage . . . . Wife clearly made the vast majority of the indirect contributions to the marriage . . . . When considered in their entirety, the contributions of each party to the marriage, both direct and indirect combined, are equal in value. Â

III.  Jurisdiction to Issue Supplemental Order 
Wife contends the family court judge did not reserve jurisdiction to issue the Supplemental Order awarding guardian ad litem fees. Â The order was issued on September 29, 2004, after both the final order dated March 11, 2004 and the order addressing post trial motions dated August 2, 2004. Wife relies on our holding in Heins v. Heins where, pursuant to Rule 59(e) SCRCP, we held the family court did not have authority to alter or amend a judgment sua sponte once the judgment was more than ten days old.Â  364 S.C. 146, 157, 543 S.E.2d 224, 229 (Ct. App. 2001). Â We find Wifeâ€™s reliance on Heins in the present case misplaced. 
First, we note the final order dated March 11, 2004 contains a provision retaining and reserving jurisdiction to issue any and all orders necessary to effectuate the terms of the order and to effectuate compliance with the terms of this order. Â Arguably, guardian ad litem fees were not terms of the March 11, 2004 order, but, in light of the judgeâ€™s Supplemental Order and recent legislation, this court determines the exclusion of the term for payment of guardian fees was an oversight.Â  
An award of guardian ad litem fees lies within the sound discretion of the family court judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion. Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 196, 612 S.E.2d 707, 714 (Ct. App. 2005). Section 20-7-1545 of the South Carolina Code provides that, in a private action in which custody or visitation is an issue, a guardian ad litem may be appointed when both parties consent to the appointment. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1545 (Supp. 2005).Â  Additionally, section 20-7-1553 requires:

(A) At the time of appointment of a guardian ad litem, the family court judge must set forth the method and rate of compensation for the guardian ad litem, including an initial authorization of a fee based on the facts of the case. If the guardian ad litem determines that it is necessary to exceed the fee initially authorized by the judge, the guardian must provide notice to both parties and obtain the judgeâ€™s written authorization of the consent of both parties to charge more than the initially authorized fee. 
    
(B) A guardian appointed by the court is entitled to reasonable compensation, subject to the review and approval of the court. In determining the reasonableness of the fees and costs, the court must take into account:
(1) the complexity of the issues before the court;
(2) the contentiousness of the litigation;
(3) the time expended by the guardian;
(4) the expenses reasonably incurred by the guardian;
(5) the financial ability of each party to pay fees and costs; and
(6) any other factors the court considers necessary.


S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1553 (A-B) (Supp. 2005).
In light of the legislatureâ€™s direction for compensating guardians ad litem, the judgeâ€™s omission of a provision for guardianâ€™s fees was an oversight. Â Rule 60(a), SCRCP, provides in pertinent part:

[c]lerical mistakes in judgments, orders or other parts of the record and errors therein arising from oversight or omission may be corrected by the court at any time of its own initiative or on the motion of any party and after such notice, if any, as the court orders. During the pendency of an appeal, leave to correct the mistake must be obtained from the appellate court. The ending of a term of court or departure from the circuit shall not operate to deprive the trial judge of jurisdiction to correct such mistakes. 

(emphasis added).Â  Therefore, the family court had jurisdiction to issue the September 29, 2004 Supplemental Order pursuant to Rule 60(a) SCRCP. 
CONCLUSION
We affirm the ruling of the family court in regard to:

(1)Â Â Â Â  the partiesâ€™ contributions to the marriage; 
(2)Â Â Â Â  the invasion of Husbandâ€™s assets for temporary support;
(3)Â Â Â Â  the award of the marital home to Wife; 
(4)Â Â Â Â  Husbandâ€™s share of childrenâ€™s private school tuition;
(5)Â Â Â Â  Husbandâ€™s share in future profits from the sale of the Â Â  marital home;
(6)Â Â Â Â  the classification of Wifeâ€™s jewelry as marital property; and
(7)Â Â Â Â  the award of guardian fees in the Supplemental Order. 

We reverse the holding of the family court in reference to the amountÂ of income imputed to Husband and remand for a determination consistent with this opinion as it relates to the calculation of the child support award. Â 
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART and REMANDED.
SHORT, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] Husband left New South with a severance package which included, in addition to other benefits, a gross income of $500,000.00 to be paid over an eighteen-month period.Â  Parties initially agreed to use the after tax income from New South, which amounted to approximately $15,000.00 monthly, to pay the $3365.18 monthly mortgage payment on the marital home and to pay non-taxable family support to Wife in the amount of $7,500.00 per month. Husband received the balance for his use.Â  The agreement was formalized by Temporary Order of Judge Amy C. Sutherland, dated April 10, 2002.Â  At that time, only six months of income remained to be disbursed from the New South severance package.Â  Consequently, the provisions of the order allowed for additional temporary relief when the New South income ended. Â Subsequent orders dated September 10, 2002, May 16, 2003, and September 10, 2003, modified the original support agreement, eventually relieving Husband of spousal support and reducing his obligation under the marital home mortgage to one-half. 
[2] Dr. Groverâ€™s deposition was not included in the record.
