title: State v. Curry
description: Curry appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, arguing the trial court erred by: (1) limiting the scope of Curry's cross-examination of two co-defendants, and (2) charging the jury on "the hand of one is the hand of all."  The majority affirms Curry's conviction, and Judge Anderson dissents.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Thaddeus Curry, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4159
Heard June 15, 2006 â€“ Filed October 9, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled February 5, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Jeffery A. Jacobs, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, Â of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Thaddeus Curry appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime in connection with the death of Heath Hamilton.Â  On appeal, Curry argues (1) the trial court erred in limiting the scope of his cross-examination of two co-defendants on sentencing exposure they faced for murder and other charges related to Hamiltonâ€™s death, and (2) the trial court erred in charging the jury on â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Shortly after midnight on March 18, 2003, Hamilton and Ronald Coursey drove to an apartment complex in Augusta, Georgia, to purchase marijuana.Â  In the apartment complexâ€™s parking lot, they encountered Anthony Savage and Curry and asked if they had any marijuana to sell.Â  Curry and Savage said they had no marijuana, but agreed to procure some and sell a quarter poundâ€™s worth to Hamilton and Coursey for $220.Â  
Hamilton and Coursey drove to an ATM and withdrew money to pay for the drugs.Â  Meanwhile, Curry, Savage, and Jeremy Simuel drove around Augusta looking for marijuana to sell to Hamilton and Coursey.Â  They were unsuccessful.Â  When they all returned to the apartment complex, Hamilton and Coursey followed Curry, Savage, and Simuel to Simuelâ€™s apartment.Â  Hamilton and Coursey waited outside the apartment while the others went inside and closed the door. They were soon informed the transaction would occur later.Â  
Hamilton and Coursey left the apartment complex and went to Hamiltonâ€™s home in Beech Island in Aiken County, where they smoked marijuana and waited until Curry and Savage called.Â  The parties spoke by phone and agreed to meet at a gas station in Beech Island.Â  Although Curry, Savage, and Simuel failed to procure marijuana to sell Hamilton and Coursey, they apparently intended to meetÂ  under the guise of a drug sale in order to rob Hamilton and Coursey. 
Hamilton and Coursey met Curry and Savage in a dark area behind the gas station.Â  Curry and Savage exited their car, where Simuel remained seated.Â  They approached the car in which Hamilton and Coursey waited.Â  Savage told Hamilton they did not have any marijuana, but demanded to see the money.Â  Within minutes, Hamilton was shot and killed while still seated in his vehicle with Coursey.Â  Curry and Savage fled in the waiting car driven by
Simuel.
Curry, Savage, and Simuel were charged in connection with the robbery and Hamiltonâ€™s murder.Â  At Curryâ€™s trial, Coursey, Savage, and Simuel implicated Curry in Hamiltonâ€™s murder.Â  Coursey testified he had not met Curry, Savage, or Simuel before the night of the murder.Â  He stated they first met around midnight in the dark parking lot of the apartment complex, a short time later at the apartment complex, and finally in the dark parking lot of the gas station where Hamilton was killed.Â  He testified he called 911 after the shooting but was unable to provide many details about the perpetrators, telling the 911 dispatcher, â€œI donâ€™t know, itâ€™s dark[,] man, I just donâ€™t know.â€Â  However, at trial Coursey testified Curry had the gun in his hand and that Savage never had possession of the gun.Â  Moreover, he unequivocally identified Curry as the shooter.Â  
Savage testified Curry carried a gun with him on the night of the murder and claimed he saw Curry fire the gun three or four times at the murder scene.Â  Savage further testified that after the shooting, Curry and he fled in a car driven by Simuel.Â  According to Savage, Curry exclaimed, â€œI think I dome capped him,â€ implying he shot Hamilton in the head.Â  Savage testified Curry later told him he had disposed of the murder weapon.Â  Simuel largely corroborated Savageâ€™s testimony but did not provide an eyewitness account of Curry firing the gun.Â  Â Â 
Curry sought to question the motives and biases of Simuel and Savage by cross-examining them on the possible sentences they faced in connection with Hamiltonâ€™s murder.Â  When Curry questioned Simuel about the possible sentences he faced, the trial court sustained the Stateâ€™s objection and instructed the jury to disregard the testimony.Â  
Prior to Savageâ€™s testimony, Curry asked the trial court in limine to allow impeachment of Savage on bias and motive by questioning him about the possible sentences he faced for charges related to Hamiltonâ€™s death.Â  The trial court denied his request. Â In reaching its decision, the trial court considered Curryâ€™s request in light of State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 563 S.E.2d 315 (2002), and stated:

Under [the circumstances in Mizzell], sir, part of the problem I think in that case was that, as I read it, the witness was given an offer to plead to one particular charge versus the potential sentence, the maximum sentence on the other charges that the defendant would have faced had she been convicted or tried on the original charges, and we donâ€™t have that here.Â  Thereâ€™s no deal between the State at all.

Curry later sought clarification, asking, â€œSo the Court is ruling that he says he has no deal, then I am prohibited from asking about these penalties that heâ€™s facing, is that correct?â€Â  The trial court responded affirmatively. Â The trial court elaborated, â€œWeâ€™re not going to bring him out here to elicit whether or not he knows what his potential sentences are.Â  As I understand it thereâ€™s no negotiations or deals between the State and this particular witness.â€Â Â  Â 
The jury convicted Curry on both charges.Â  He received concurrent prison sentences of five years for the firearms charge and life in prison for the murder charge.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Scope of Cross-examination 
Curry argues the trial court committed reversible error in denying his request to cross-examine Simuel and Savage concerning possible sentences he faced in connection with Hamiltonâ€™s death. [1]Â  We disagree.
To constitute error, a ruling to admit or exclude evidence must affect a substantial right. Â Rule 103(a), SCRE; State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 60, 609 S.E.2d 520, 524 (2005).Â  However, error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the trialâ€™s outcome. Â State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985).Â  In considering whether error is harmless, a caseâ€™s particular facts must be considered along with various factors including:

. . . the importance of the witnessâ€™ testimony in the prosecutionâ€™s case, whether the testimony was cumulative, the presence or absence of evidence corroborating or contradicting the testimony of the witness on material points, the extent of cross-examination otherwise permitted, and, of course, the overall strength of the prosecutionâ€™s case.

State v. Clark, 315 S.C. 478, 482, 445 S.E.2d 633, 637 (1994).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where â€œguilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.â€ State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989). Â A violation of a defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront a witness is not per se reversible error if the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v. Graham, 314 S.C. 383, 385, 444 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1994). 
In this case, Curry relied on State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 563 S.E.2d 315 (2002), in support of his argument that he should be allowed to cross-examine his co-defendants as to any possible sentences they faced in connection with Hamiltonâ€™s death.Â  In Mizzell, our Supreme Court found error in the trial courtâ€™s decision to exclude evidence of possible sentences faced by Mizzellâ€™s co-defendant where the parties faced the same charges and the co-defendant had not yet pled guilty or reached a plea agreement with the State.Â  The court found:

The fact the witness has yet to reach a plea bargain or been found guilty should not prevent the admission of such evidence. The lack of a negotiated plea, if anything, creates a situation where the witness is more likely to engage in biased testimony in order to obtain a future recommendation for leniency. 

Id. at 333, 563 S.E.2d at 318. Â Â 
Similar to the scenario in Mizzell, Curryâ€™s co-defendants faced the same charges as Curry and had not pled guilty or reached a plea agreement.Â  The trial court refused to allow Curry to cross-examine his co-defendants on the possible sentences they faced because Savage and Simuel had not pled guilty or reached a plea agreement with the State.Â  We find this ruling contradicts the settled law established in Mizzell.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court erred in barring the cross-examination of Simuel and Savage on the possible sentences they faced.
However, the refusal to allow Curry to cross-examine his co-defendants on any possible sentences they faced in connection with Hamiltonâ€™s death was harmless.Â  At trial, the testimony given by the co-defendants was not the only evidence of Curryâ€™s involvement in the shooting of Hamilton.Â  Ronald Coursey, the other victim of the robbery, unequivocally identified Curry as the shooter.Â  He testified:

Coursey: And then the next I knew, he came up, Mr. Curry, over there had the gun.
Q: You saw Mr. Curry with the gun?
A: Yes, sir, he had the gun the whole time.
Q: What did he do with the gun?
A: â€¦ he started shooting.
â€¦
Q:Â  Could you describe the gun?
A: â€¦it was either automatic or semi-automatic.Â  It went off real fast.
Q: And how was [Curry] holding it?
A: In one hand.
Q: Okay.Â  And so what did he say when he pulled the gun out?
A: I donâ€™t think he said anything, it just happened too fast and he shot and hit [Hamilton] in the head.
â€¦
Q: Did you see who pulled the trigger?
A: Yes, sir. It was Mr. Curry over there.

Moreover, in addition to Coursey, Javon Rushon provided the following testimony regarding a conversation he overheard between Curry and Savage regarding the murder weapon:

Q: What specifically did you hear Mr. Curryâ€”what if anything, did you hear Mr. Curry mention about the gun?
A: â€œThey would never find it.â€Â  â€œThe hammer came off of it.â€Â  You know, â€œIt was chopped up.â€

On cross-examination, Rushon further clarified that it was in fact Curry who was talking about the gun, stating â€œThaddeus Curry was talking to [Savage] about it.â€Â  
The testimony of the co-defendants, Simuel and Savage, was merely cumulative to that given by Coursey and Rushon.Â  As a result, Curryâ€™s guilt or innocence did not hinge solely on the testimony of his co-defendants; the testimony of Coursey and Rushon provided other competent evidence upon which a rational verdict of guilty could be based.Â  Therefore, as the error on the part of the trial judge in limiting the scope of cross-examination could not have reasonably affected the outcome of the trial, it was harmless.[2]
II.  Jury Charge
Curry next argues the trial court erred in its charge on â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory.Â  We disagree.
â€œA charge is sufficient if, when considered as a whole, it covers the law applicable to the case.â€Â  State v. Ezell, 321 S.C. 421, 425, 468 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œThe substance of the law is what must be charged to the jury, not any particular verbiage.â€Â  State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 318-19, 577 S.E.2d 460, 464 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œJury instructions must be considered as a whole and, if as a whole, they are free from error, any isolated portions which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  State v. Jackson, 297 S.C. 523, 526, 377 S.E.2d 570, 572 (1989).Â  
At trial, Curry argued the courtâ€™s proposed charge on â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory lacked â€œsufficient emphasis on the issue of probable or natural consequence . . . .â€Â  Based on language drawn from State v. Dickman, 341 S.C. 293, 534 S.E.2d 268 (2000), Curry suggested the following charge:

[I]f two or more combine together to commit an unlawful act and a crime is committed by one of the actors as a probable and natural consequence of the acts done in pursuance of the common design, all present and participating in the unlawful undertaking are as guilty as the one who committed the act.

(emphasis added).Â  
The trial judge rejected Curryâ€™s proposed charge.Â  He subsequently charged the jury twice on â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory.Â  The first charge, which he gave along with the other charges prior to jury deliberations, stated:

It is my duty to charge you now that if a crime is committed by two or more people who are acting together in committing a crime, the act of one is the act of all.Â  If a person joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose, he is criminally responsible for everything done by the other person which occurs as a natural consequence of the acts done in carrying out the common plan and purpose.

After the jury left to deliberate, Curry renewed his objection to the charge on the basis that â€œthe instruction as given did not convey to the jury that the act in this case, a homicide, must be a natural or probable consequence of the preexisting plan in order . . . for the theory of the hand of one, hand of all to apply. . . .â€ (emphasis added).Â  The trial judge noted Curryâ€™s exception.
During its deliberation, the jury asked the court to re-charge â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all.â€Â  The court brought the jury out and charged accomplice liability as follows, in pertinent part:

[I]f a crime is committed by two or more people who are acting together in committing a crime, the act of one is the act of all.Â  I tell you further that a person who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is criminally responsible for everything done by the other person which occurs as a natural consequence of the acts done in carrying out the common plan or purpose.Â  When two or more people are acting together â€¦ assisting each other in committing the offense the act of one is the act of all, or as is sometimes said, the hand of one is the hand of all.

(emphasis added).Â  
South Carolina courts frequently approve accomplice liability charges that lack language stating an accompliceâ€™s criminal act must be â€œa probable and natural consequenceâ€ of the accompliceâ€™s common plan.Â  For instance, in State v. Langley, 334 S.C. 643, 515 S.E.2d 98 (1999), our supreme court stated that under â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory, â€œone who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of the common design and purpose.â€Â  In State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 76-77, 502 S.E.2d 63, 76 (1998), the supreme court approved a broader accomplice liability charge that stated, â€œâ€¦ if a crime is committed by two or more persons who are acting together in the commission of a crime, then the act of one is the act of both.â€ Moreover, in State v. Crowe our Supreme Court approved the following charge for accomplice liability:Â Â Â Â  

[T]wo or more combine together to commit an unlawful act, such as robbery, and, in the execution of that criminal act, a homicide is committed by one of the actors, as a probable or natural consequence of the acts done in pursuance of the common design, all present participating in the unlawful undertaking are as guilty as the one who committed the fatal act. This principle was stated in State v. Cannon, 49 S.C. 550, 27 S.E. 526:Â  â€œThe common purpose may not have been to kill and murder, but if it was unlawful, as, for instance, to break in and steal, and in the execution of this common purpose a homicide is committed by one, as a
probable or natural consequence of the acts done in pursuance of the common design, then all present participating in the unlawful common design are as guilty as the slayer.â€

258 S.C. 258, 265, 188 S.E.2d 379, 382 (1972) (emphases added).Â  Therefore, the approval of this charge demonstrates that the â€œnatural and probable consequenceâ€ language need not be included in the charge, as requested by Curry, if the charge as a whole adequately conveys the law.Â  Additionally, with the approval of the disjunctive â€œorâ€ in the â€œprobable or natural consequenceâ€ language of State v. Crowe, the trial courtâ€™s charge arguably benefited Curry as it only included the â€œnatural consequencesâ€ rather than the â€œnatural or probableâ€ language.
Therefore, when viewing the challenged portion of the jury charge as a whole with the rest of the trial courtâ€™s instruction, we find the trial court adequately charged the law regarding â€œhand of one hand of all.â€Â  
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, Curryâ€™s conviction is hereby
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, J. concurs.
ANDERSON, J. dissents in a separate opinion.
ANDERSON, J. Simuel.

Savage asseverated Curry carried a gun with him on the night of the murder, and claimed he saw Curry fire the gun three or four times at the murder scene.Â  Savage further testified that after the shooting, Curry and he fled in a car driven by Simuel.Â  According to Savage, Curry exclaimed, â€œI think I dome capped him,â€ indicating he shot Hamilton in the head.Â  Curry later told Savage he had disposed of the murder weapon.Â  Simuel largely corroborated Savageâ€™s testimony, but did not provide an eyewitness account of Curry firing the gun.Â

Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 563 S.E.2d 315 (2002), and stated:

Under [the circumstances in Mizzell], sir, part of the problem I think in that case was that, as I read it, the witness was given an offer to plead to one particular charge versus the potential sentence, the maximum sentence on the other charges that the defendant would have faced had she been convicted or tried on the original charges, and we donâ€™t have that here.Â  Thereâ€™s no deal between the State at all.

I.Â  Limitation of Cross-Examination
A.Â  Confrontation Right
Curry argues the trial court committed reversible error in denying his request to cross-examine Savage and Simuel concerning the possible sentences they faced in connection with Hamiltonâ€™s death.Â  I agree.
â€œAmong other protections, the Sixth Amendment assures: â€˜In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right . . . to be confronted with the witnesses against him[.]â€™Â  U.S. Const. amend. VI.â€Â  State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 372, 613 S.E.2d 760, 764 (Ct. App. 2005), cert. granted (Feb. 15, 2006).Â  The Sixth Amendment was incorporated and made applicable to the states through the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.Â  Pointer v. Texas, 380 U.S. 400 (1965); State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 563 S.E.2d 315 (2002); Davis, 364 S.C. at 372, 613 S.E.2d at 764.Â  The right of confrontation is essential to a fair trial in that it promotes reliability in criminal trials and insures that convictions will not result from testimony of individuals who cannot be challenged at trial.Â

Brown, 303 S.C. 169, 171, 399 S.E.2d 593, 594 (1991).Â  Considerable latitude is allowed in cross-examining a witness for potential bias from which jurors could draw inferences relating to the witnessâ€™s liability. Â State v. Clark, 315 S.C. 478, 481, 445 S.E.2d 633, 634 (1994); Brown, 303 S.C. at 171, 399 S.E.2d at 594.Â  However, the Confrontation Clause does not preclude the trial court from limiting a defendantâ€™s inquiry into the potential bias of a prosecution witness.Â 
Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673 (1986); Gillian, 360 S.C. at 451, 602 S.E.2d at 72.Â  Rather, the trial court retains broad discretion to impose reasonable limits on such cross-examination based on concerns about issues including harassment, prejudice, confusion of the issues, witness safety, or interrogation that is repetitive or only marginally relevant. Â Id.Â  
In State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 563 S.E.2d 315 (2002), our supreme court found error in the trial courtâ€™s decision to exclude evidence of possible sentences faced by the Mizzell brothersâ€™ co-defendants where all defendants faced the same charges and the co-defendants had not yet pled guilty or reached a plea agreement with the State. Â The Mizzell brothers were tried together on charges of first degree burglary, grand larceny, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime for breaking into the victimâ€™s home and stealing several guns.Â  Stateâ€™s witness Donald Steele had been charged with the same crimes as the Mizzells.Â  Steele testified that he and his wife drove the Mizzells to the victimâ€™s home and watched as they kicked in the door, entered the home, and returned carrying guns.Â  On cross-examination, Steele admitted the State had charged him with the same crimes as the Mizzells.Â  â€œThe trial court excluded evidence of the possible sentence Steele faced but permitted petitioners to examine Steele about the sentence in general terms.â€Â  349 S.C. at 330, 563 S.E.2d at 317.Â  
The issue for the court was whether the trial court had violated the defendantsâ€™ confrontation rights by refusing to allow evidence of Steeleâ€™s potential sentence if convicted of the same crimes as the Mizzells.Â  The Mizzell court began by juxtaposing the right of a defendant to cross-examine a witness with the discretion of a trial judge to dictate reasonable limits on the scope of cross-examination:

A criminal defendant may show a violation of the Confrontation Clause â€œby showing that he was prohibited from engaging in otherwise appropriate cross-examination designed to show a prototypical form of bias on the part of the witness, and thereby â€˜to expose to the jury the facts from which jurors . . . could appropriately draw inferences relating to the reliability of the witness.â€™â€ Â Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673, 680, 106 S.Ct. 1431, 1436, 89 L.Ed.2d 674, 684 (1986). Â The trial judge retains discretion to impose reasonable limits on the scope of cross-examination. Â State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991); accord Delaware v. Van Arsdall, supra. Â Before a trial judge may limit a criminal defendantâ€™s right to engage in cross-examination to show bias on the part of the witness, the record must clearly show the cross-examination is inappropriate. Â State v. Graham, supra. Â If the defendant establishes he was unfairly prejudiced by the limitation, it is reversible error. Â State v. Brown, supra.

Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 331, 563 S.E.2d at 317.Â  The court elaborated that â€œ[t]he jury is, generally, not entitled to learn the possible sentence of a defendant because the sentence is irrelevant to finding guilt or innocence.â€Â  Id. at 331, 563 S.E.2d at 318.Â  â€œHowever,â€ the court intoned, â€œother constitutional concerns, such as the Confrontation Clause, limit the applicability of this rule in circumstances where the defendantâ€™s right to effectively cross-examine a co-conspirator witness of possible bias outweighs the need to exclude the evidence.â€Â  Id. at 331-32, 563 S.E.2d at 318.Â  
The court discussed State v. Brown, 303 S.C. 169, 399 S.E.2d 593 (1991), a case in which a witness admitted she testified in exchange for a conspiracy charge which carried a seven and one-half year maximum sentence, rather than a trafficking in cocaine charge.Â  The trial judge refused to allow the defense to cross-examine the witness as to the maximum punishment she would have faced under the trafficking charge.Â  The Brown court found that evidence the witness was avoiding a mandatory prison term of â€œmore than three times the duration she would face on her plea to conspiracyâ€ constituted â€œcritical evidence of potential bias that appellant should have been permitted to present to the jury.â€Â  Brown, 303 S.C. at 171, 399 S.E.2d at 594. Â Further, the witnessâ€™s testimony was the only evidence linking Brown to trafficking cocaine.Â  
The Mizzell court noted that unlike in Brown, Steele did not have a deal with the State.Â  However, the court concluded that the lack of an agreement with the prosecution would make the potential for witness bias even more likely:

The fact the witness has yet to reach a plea bargain or been found guilty should not prevent the admission of such evidence. The lack of a negotiated plea, if anything, creates a situation where the witness is more likely to engage in biased testimony in order to obtain a future recommendation for leniency. 

Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 333, 563 S.E.2d at 318.Â  Thus, Mizzell stands for the proposition that the lack of an agreement with the State may increase the likelihood of witness bias where the witness has been charged with the same crimes as the defendant. Â Â  
Similar to the scenario in Mizzell, Curryâ€™s co-defendants faced the same charges as Curry and had not pled guilty or reached a plea agreement.Â  Here, the trial court refused to allow Curry to cross-examine his co-defendants on their sentencing exposure because Savage and Simuel had not pled guilty or reached a plea agreement with the State.Â  This ruling contradicts the law established in Mizzell.Â  
State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 62 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted (Feb. 16, 2006), likewise addressed the Confrontation Clause in the context of questioning a witness on a potential sentence.Â  Gillian was convicted of murder.Â  He had coordinated a burglary and recruited several teenagers, including Stateâ€™s witness Page, to break into the home.Â  Among the items stolen was a .38 revolver which was later used to kill the victim, Michael Ward.Â  At Gillianâ€™s trial, Page testified to Gillianâ€™s possession of the gun, to Gillianâ€™s statement that he was going to â€œdo some dirtâ€ with it, and to an altercation between Gillian and the victim on the night of the murder.Â  â€œOn direct examination, Page admitted he was currently charged with first-degree burglary and the Richland County Solicitor had agreed to advise his plea judge of his cooperation in Gillianâ€™s trial.â€Â  360 S.C. at 449, 602 S.E.2d at 70.Â  Defense counsel sought to cross-examine Page on the possible sentence he faced, but the trial judge limited references to the sentence to â€œa lot of timeâ€ and â€œserious time.â€Â  Id.Â  Relying on Mizzell and State v. Sims, 348 S.C. 16, 558 S.E.2d 518 (2002), we inculcated:

Included in the Confrontation Clause protection is the right to cross-examine any Stateâ€™s witness as to possible sentences faced when there exists â€œa substantial possibility [the witness] would give biased testimony in an effort to have the solicitor highlight to [a] future [court]â€ how the witness cooperated in the instant case. Â See Sims, 348 S.C. at 25, 558 S.E.2d at 523; see also Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 332-33, 563 S.E.2d at 318. 

Gillian, 360 S.C. at 454, 602 S.E.2d at 73. Â Accordingly, we found the trial court had erred in excluding evidence of Pageâ€™s potential sentence. Â 
Apodictically, a defendant has a protected right under the Sixth Amendmentâ€™s Confrontation Clause to cross-examine a witness as to the possible sentence he faces where there exists a substantial possibility of bias.Â  In the case sub judice, where the witnesses were charged with the same crimes as the co-defendant against whom they were testifying, the requisite potential for bias was present.Â  Curry had a right to question on the possible sentences Simuel and Savage were facing, and the trial court erred by refusing this inquiry.
B.Â  Harmless Error Analysis
A determination that the trial court committed error does not end the inquiry.Â  A violation of a defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront a witness is not per se reversible error if the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v. Graham, 314 S.C. 383, 385, 444 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1994). Â In State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 454, 602 S.E.2d 62, 73 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted (Feb. 16, 2006), this Court stated the law of harmless error with exactitude:

No definite rule of law governs the finding that an error was harmless; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 391 S.E.2d 241 (1990); State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 336 S.E.2d 150 (1985); State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. App. 2004). Whether an error is harmless depends on the particular facts of each case and upon a host of factors, including: 
  
the importance of the witnessâ€™ testimony in the prosecutionâ€™s case, whether the testimony was cumulative, the presence or absence of evidence corroborating or contradicting the testimony of the witness on material points, the extent of cross-examination otherwise permitted, and of course the overall strength of the prosecutionâ€™s case. 
  
Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 333, 563 S.E.2d at 318-19 (quoting Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673, 684, 106 S.Ct. 1431, 89 L.Ed.2d 674 (1986)).
â€œHarmless beyond a reasonable doubtâ€ means the reviewing court can conclude the error did not contribute to the verdict beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 334, 563 S.E.2d at 319; Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 420 S.E.2d 834 (1992).Â  â€œIn determining whether an error is harmless, the reviewing court must review the entire record to determine what effect the error had on the verdict.â€Â  Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 334, 563 S.E.2d at 319 (internal quotations omitted).
Error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003); Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151; State v. Burton, 326 S.C. 605, 486 S.E.2d 762 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â 
State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 377 S.E.2d 581 (1989); Adams, 354 S.C. at 381, 580 S.E.2d at 795; see also State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 460 S.E.2d 368 (1995) (noting that when guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other rational conclusion could be reached, this Court will not set aside conviction for insubstantial errors not affecting result).

Gillian, 360 S.C. at 454-55, 602 S.E.2d at 74-75.
The Mizzell court found the erroneous limitation of the cross-examination of a witness constituted reversible error under the facts of that case.Â  Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 334, 563 S.E.2d at 319.Â  The court noted the witnessâ€™s testimony provided the only direct link between the defendant and the crime scene.Â  Moreover, no physical evidence linked the defendant to the crime scene.Â  In fact, nothing else corroborated the Stateâ€™s case.
Conversely, in State v. Sims, 348 S.C. 16, 26, 558 S.E.2d 518, 523 (2002), our supreme court found harmless error where the Stateâ€™s case was â€œstrongâ€ without the witnessâ€™s testimony and exclusion of the testimony could not possibly have affected the trialâ€™s outcome.Â  In considering the strength of the Stateâ€™s case, the Sims court noted the defendantâ€™s fingerprints were found at the crime scene, the victimâ€™s mother testified Sims threatened the victim on the date of her death, and Sims had â€œspontaneously confessedâ€ to law enforcement officers investigating the incident.Â  Id.
This Court found harmless error in Gillian, where the witnessâ€™s testimony was â€œlargely cumulativeâ€ to testimony from other witnesses and other evidence suggested Gillianâ€™s guilt.Â  Gillian, 360 S.C. at 457-58, 602 S.E.2d at 74-75.Â  We distinguished the facts in Gillian from those in Mizzell, noting the absence of the witnessâ€™s testimony left â€œno material point of the Stateâ€™s case uncorroborated or unsupported by the testimony of other witnesses.â€Â  Id. at 458, 602 S.E.2d at 75.
Here, Simuel and Savageâ€™s testimony was critical to the caseâ€™s outcome.Â  They testified to Curryâ€™s motive; to his possession of a gun similar to that used in the shooting; to his conduct before and after the shooting; and to self-incriminating statements Curry made about discarding the weapon.Â  Most significantly, Savage testified to seeing Curry fire the gun.Â  Without their testimony, the only evidence linking Curry to the crime scene is Courseyâ€™s vague and unspecific testimony.Â  Coursey provided few details of the gunman in the description he provided to the 911 dispatcher immediately after the shooting and in his written statement to police made one week later.Â Â  Coursey testified the shooting occurred in a dark area, and that he met Curry and Savage for the first time hours before in another dark location.Â  Moreover, Coursey testified he observed the shooting after spending several hours drinking alcohol and smoking marijuana.Â  Consequently, the testimony of Simuel and Savage provided the crucial nexus establishing Curry as the gunman.Â  
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s error in limiting Curryâ€™s cross-examination could have reasonably affected the outcome of the trial.Â  The error was not harmless.Â  
II.Â  Accomplice Liability Charge
Additionally, Curry maintains the trial courtâ€™s charge on the hand of one is the hand of all theory was inadequate because it failed to specify that a crime committed by an accomplice must be a â€œprobable or natural consequenceâ€ of the actions taken in pursuit of the accomplicesâ€™ common plan.Â  I agree.Â  Although the courtâ€™s charge included the words â€œnatural consequence,â€ the charge should have included both â€œnaturalâ€ and â€œprobable.â€
At trial, Curry argued the courtâ€™s proposed charge on â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory lacked â€œsufficient emphasis on the issue of probable or natural consequence[.]â€Â  Based on language drawn from State v. Dickman, 341 S.C. 293, 534 S.E.2d 268 (2000), Curry suggested the following charge:

[I]f two or more combine together to commit an unlawful act and a crime is committed by one of the actors as a probable and natural consequence of the acts done in pursuance of the common design, all present and participating in the unlawful undertaking are as guilty as the one who committed the act.

(Emphasis added.)Â  
The trial judge rejected Curryâ€™s proposed charge and subsequently charged the jury twice on â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory.Â  The first charge, which the judge gave along with the other charges prior to jury deliberations, stated:

It is my duty to charge you now that if a crime is committed by two or more people who are acting together in committing a crime, the act of one is the act of all.Â  If a person joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose, he is criminally responsible for everything done by the other person which occurs as a natural consequence of the acts done in carrying out the common plan and purpose.

(Emphasis added.)Â  After the jury left to deliberate, Curry renewed his objection to the charge on the basis that â€œthe instruction as given did not convey to the jury that the act in this case, a homicide, must be a natural or probable consequence of the preexisting plan in order . . . for the theory of the hand of one, hand of all to apply. . . .â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The trial judge noted Curryâ€™s exception.
During its deliberations, the jury asked the court to re-charge â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all.â€Â  The court brought the jury out and charged accomplice liability as follows:

. . . if a crime is committed by two or more people who are acting together in committing a crime, the act of one is the act of all.Â  I tell you further that a person who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is criminally responsible for everything done by the other person which occurs as a natural consequence of the acts done in carrying out the common plan or purpose.Â  When two or more people are acting together . . . assisting each other in committing the offense the act of one is the act of all, or as is sometimes said, the hand of one is the hand of all.

(Emphasis added.)Â  After re-charging the jury on additional areas of law, including mere presence, the trial judge sent the jury back for continued deliberation.Â  The judge stated to Curryâ€™s counsel, â€œI note your continuing objection to the charge on hand of one as stated earlier.â€Â  
Curry argues the accomplice liability charge erroneously failed to specify that an accompliceâ€™s crime must be â€œa probable and natural consequenceâ€ of actions taken in pursuit of the accomplicesâ€™ shared plan.Â  The language advanced by Curry limits criminal liability for an accompliceâ€™s actions that are inconsequential to the execution of their common scheme or plan.Â  As one treatise explains:

When several persons are involved in the perpetration of one crime, and one of them goes outside the common purpose for which they combined or conspired in committing a fatal act which is not a natural and probable consequence of carrying out the common purpose, the others are not criminally liable for the homicide.Â  There is a requirement of a direct causal connection between the underlying felony and the homicide which is something more than mere coincidence in time and place between the two. The actual legal relation between the killing and the crime committed or attempted must be such that the killing can be said to have occurred as a part of the perpetration of the crime, or in furtherance of an attempt to commit it; that is, the fatal act must have been the ordinary, probable, or necessary result or effect of the execution of the conspiracy, or of the concerted action, in which the defendant participated.
Whether or not the act done was in furtherance of the common design, or whether it was a natural and probable consequence flowing from the execution of the common design is always a question for the jury.

3 Am.Jur. Proof of Facts 2d 551, Homicide Outside of Common Design, Â§ 6 (2005) (emphasis added). 
Our courts have approved of accomplice liability charges that lack language stating an accompliceâ€™s criminal act must be â€œa probable and natural consequenceâ€ of the accomplicesâ€™ common plan.Â  For instance, in State v. Langley, 334 S.C. 643, 648, 515 S.E.2d 98, 101 (1999), our supreme court stated that under â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory, â€œone who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of the common design and purpose.â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â Â Â  In State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 76-77, 502 S.E.2d 63, 76 (1998), the supreme court approved a broader accomplice liability charge that stated, â€œ. . . if a crime is committed by two or more persons who are acting together in the commission of a crime, then the act of one is the act of both.â€Â Â  
However, other cases present accomplice liability charges that include the language Curry requests.Â  In State v. Crowe, 258 S.C. 258, 265, 188 S.E.2d 379, 382 (1972), our supreme court described accomplice liability as whereÂ Â Â  

. . . two or more combine together to commit an unlawful act, such as robbery, and, in the execution of that criminal act, a homicide is committed by one of the actors, as a probable or natural consequence of the acts done in pursuance of the common design, all present participating in the unlawful undertaking are as guilty as the one who committed the fatal act. This principle was stated in State v. Cannon, 49 S.C. 550, 27 S.E. 526:Â  â€œThe common purpose may not have been to kill and murder, but if it was unlawful, as, for instance, to break in and steal, and in the execution of this common purpose a homicide is committed by one, as a probable or natural consequence of the acts done in pursuance of the common design, then all present participating in the unlawful common design are as guilty as the slayer.â€

(Emphasis added.)Â Â  

In State v. Peterson, 287 S.C. 244, 335 S.E.2d 800 (1985), revâ€™d on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991), our supreme court considered the necessity of the â€œprobable or natural consequenceâ€ language in an accomplice liability charge.Â  Peterson involved the joint appeal of two accomplices who appealed their convictions for murder, armed robbery, grand larceny of a motor vehicle, and conspiracy.Â  The court stated:
The trial judgeâ€™s charge was a correct statement of the general law of this jurisdiction concerning accomplice liability.Â  In the present case, however, the jury reasonably could have found that the murder was not the probable or natural consequence of the larceny of a motor vehicle.
Had the jury determined that either appellant conspired only to commit an unarmed larceny of a car, and had it further concluded that the state failed to establish beyond a reasonable doubt that a homicide was the natural or probable consequence of a plan to steal the victimâ€™s car, the appellant would have been entitled to an acquittal on the charge of murder.
It was therefore essential under the facts and circumstances of this case that the jury be instructed that it had to find that the homicide was a natural or probable consequence of the acts actually agreed on by the appellants before the law would hold him responsible for such a homicide.Â  The failure of the trial judge to so instruct was error because it permitted the jury to convict an appellant of murder merely by finding (1) that appellant had combined with another to commit the non-life threatening crime of grand larceny of a motor vehicle and (2) that appellantâ€™s accomplice thereafter took a life without appellantâ€™s prior knowledge, approval, or assistance.

Peterson, 287 S.C. at 246-47, 335 S.E.2d at 801-02 (emphasis added).
Thus, the facts and circumstances of a particular case ultimately dictate whether an accomplice liability charge must instruct the jury that an accompliceâ€™s actions be a â€œnatural or probable consequenceâ€ of actions taken in pursuit of the accomplicesâ€™ shared plan.
I would hold that here, as in Peterson, the facts and circumstances warrant the language requested by Curry.Â  Evidence presented at trial suggested the possibility that the codefendants met Hamilton and Coursey under the pretense of selling them marijuana, but in fact had no marijuana to sell and only intended to rob them of their money.Â  The testimony is not conclusive that the codefendants agreed to use weapons to accomplish the crime; only that one of them apparently had the intention and shot Hamilton during the commission of the crime.Â  Had the jury determined that either codefendant conspired only to commit an unarmed robbery and had it further concluded that the State failed to establish beyond a reasonable doubt that a homicide was the natural or probable consequence of the robbery, the appellant would have been entitled to an acquittal on the charge of murder.Â  Crowe and Peterson utilize both â€œnaturalâ€ and â€œprobable.â€Â  Each word has a different meaning.Â  Accordingly, the use of both words was necessary in the case sub judice.Â  The courtâ€™s failure to include the word â€œprobableâ€ here renders the charge inadequate. 
Curry further alleges the trial court erred (1) by refusing to allow him to cross-examine Savage on possible sentence he faced for pending charges unrelated to Hamiltonâ€™s death; (2) by allowing testimony regarding alleged bad acts; and (3) by allowing the State to elicit testimony that Curry was in jail at the time of the trial.Â  Because I would reverse on the Confrontation Clause and accomplice liability charge issues, I decline to address these issues.Â  I VOTE to REVERSE.

[1] Curry also argues the trial court erred in refusing to allow him to cross-examine Savage about pending criminal charges unrelated to Hamiltonâ€™s murder.Â  Curry never proffered the evidence or even attempted to proffer it.Â  The evidence is not part of the record.Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved.Â  See State v. Hawkins, 310 S.C. 50, 54, 425 S.E.2d 50, 57 (Ct. App. 1991) (declining to rule on alleged error in exclusion of evidence, where no proffer was made and excluded evidence was not part of record).Â  Lastly, Curry argues the trial court erred in admitting evidence that he was incarcerated.Â  This issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003) (â€œA party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground on appeal.â€).
[2] Curry also argues the trial court erred in admitting improper character or habit evidence during Savageâ€™s testimony.Â  Curry contends the testimony regarding â€œthe black bagâ€ where Curry allegedly kept his gun was inadmissible under Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  Any possible error by the circuit court was harmless given the other evidence admitted at trial.Â  See State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (finding that error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial).

title: Auten v. Snipes
description: This appeal concerns whether a separation agreement between the defendant and her now deceased former husband had the effect of extinguishing any interest the defendant had in the decedent's IRA account.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Leila Eugenia Auten, Personal Representative of the Estate of Millard Benton Parrish, Jr., deceased,
Appellant,
v.
Sylvia Snipes, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4160
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Philip E. Wright, of Lancaster, for Appellant.
Francis L. Bell, Jr. and William J. Nowicki, both of Lancaster, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Â Leila Eugenia Auten, the sister of Millard Benton Parrish, Jr., and personal representative of his estate, instituted this action to recover funds from Parrishâ€™s retirement account that were disbursed to his ex-wife, Sylvia Snipes.Â  The trial court held Auten failed to meet her burden of proving a separation agreement between Parrish and Snipes had the effect of extinguishing any interest Snipes had in the account.Â  Auten appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On April 18, 2000, Parrish rolled his 401K into a Roth IRA with Signator Investments.Â  Parrish named Snipes, his wife at the time, as primary beneficiary to receive the proceeds of the account upon his death.Â  Â 
Parrish and Snipes later separated.Â  On April 9, 2001, they executed a separation agreement providing in pertinent part as follows: Â 

Husband and wife will each keep all money and bank accounts and 401K plans and profit sharing plans which are in his or her name. . . .
. . .
LASTLY, IT IS UNDERSTOOD AND AGREED that the Husband and Wife release and forever discharge the other of and from all causes of action, claims, property rights or any demands whatsoever in law or in equity . . . and the parties to each declare this to be a full, final and complete settlement of all of their property rights, and each party does hereby release and relinquish unto the other all of his or her rights, title, claim, interest and demand, rights of dower in and to the property of the other, whether now in being or hereinafter acquired . . . . 

(Boldface in original.)Â  Contemporaneous with the separation agreement, Parrish executed a power of attorney, which allowed Snipes to proceed with a divorce in the Dominican Republic.Â  By decree dated May 23, 2001, a judge in the Dominican Republic dissolved the marriage.[2]Â  Soon after the divorce, Snipes remarried.Â  Even after execution of the separation agreement and the divorce, Parrish never changed his will or the beneficiary designation on the Signator account. 
Parrish died September 20, 2002.Â  In May 2003, Snipes contacted Signator Investments and received the balance of the account, totaling $114,582.52. 
On June 13, 2003, Auten, on behalf of Parrishâ€™s estate, sued Snipes for the proceeds of the Signator account and other relief.Â  On August 26, 2003, Snipes filed her answer and counterclaim.Â  
The trial court, sitting without a jury, held a final hearing in the case on November 16, 2004.Â  By that time, the parties had dismissed or resolved all matters in this litigation except for Autenâ€™s claim for recovery of the funds in the Signator account. 
On May 20, 2005, the trial court issued an order denying Auten the relief she requested.Â  In the order, the trial court made the following findings: Â (1) because the agreement did not specifically address a retirement account in which one spouse possessed an expectancy as a named beneficiary, the general language of the separation agreement by which Snipes purportedly waived her beneficiary interest in the Signator account was ineffective; and (2) Parrish failed to change the beneficiary on the Signator account notwithstanding that he had both the ability and ample time to do so.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In South Carolina, the construction of a separation agreement is a matter of contract law.[3]Â  Whether the language of a contract is ambiguous is a question of law for the court.[4] Â The construction of a clear and unambiguous contract is a matter for the court to decide.[5] Â â€œWhere a contract
is capable of legal construction, the courtâ€™s only function is to interpret its lawful meaning, discover the intention of the parties as found within the agreement, and give effect to it.â€[6]
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We reject Autenâ€™s challenge to the trial courtâ€™s conclusions that (1) the general release language in the agreement was not intended as a relinquishment of Snipesâ€™s claim to the proceeds in the Signator account; and (2) the agreement was not intended to operate as a relinquishment of Snipesâ€™s right to be the designated beneficiary of Parrishâ€™s retirement account.
In Stribling v. Stribling, this court recently observed that â€œ[g]enerally, in South Carolina, divorce does not per se affect the rights of a beneficiary interest. . . . However, it is generally recognized that a beneficiary may contract away the beneficiary interest through a separation or property settlement agreement, even if the beneficiary designation is not formally changed.â€ [7] Â  
Nevertheless, such a relinquishment requires more than â€œgeneral language of releaseâ€ in the separation or property settlement agreement.[8]Â  As this court went on to state in Stribling:

[I]n South Carolina, a separation agreement may preclude a named beneficiary from recovery of an expectancy interest in two ways.Â  First, a named beneficiary may be precluded from recovery when a separation agreement specifically addresses a particular policy/account providing an expectancy interest and the agreement contains language of release applicable to the policy/account. Second, when a separation agreement provides general language of release without specifically addressing the policy/account providing the expectancy interest, a named beneficiary may be precluded from recovery when the policy/account owner intended for the general waiver to apply to the expectancy interest.[9]

We hold the first method by which the agreement could have precluded Snipesâ€™s expectancy interest in the funds is inapplicable here.Â  The trial court correctly determined the separation agreement did not specifically address a retirement account in which one spouse had an expectancy interest as a named beneficiary.Â  Rather, the agreement merely awarded Parrish and Snipes the retirement accounts that were in his or her name respectively and had no explicit provisions regarding beneficiary interests.[10]Â  Furthermore, the agreement had only general release language and did not specifically require Parrish and Snipes to waive their expectancy interests in each otherâ€™s retirement accounts.Â  Thus, by the terms of the separation agreement, Snipes did not waive her beneficiary interest in the Signator account.[11]
Likewise, Auten cannot rely on the second way that a separation agreement can prevent a named beneficiary from recovering an expectancy interest.Â  We found no evidence in the record before us suggesting Parrish intended the waiver to apply to a beneficiary interest in his retirement account.Â  Significantly, Auten did not challenge the trial courtâ€™s finding that Parrish never attempted to change the beneficiary designation on the Signator account during the seventeen months between the time of the divorce until his death even though he was able to do so.[12]Â  In addition, although, as Auten argued, there were plausible reasons that Parrish would not desire to leave his retirement funds to Snipes,[13] these motives do not necessarily lead to the conclusion that he no longer intended her to be the beneficiary of those funds in the event she survived him.[14]  
2.Â  Auten argues the trial court erred in failing to make a â€œspecific findingâ€ that the separation agreement was unambiguous.Â  Auten contends that, although the trial court found â€œ[t]he appellant, through her attorney, presented in open court that the [a]greement was unambiguous,â€ this was not a â€œspecific finding.â€Â  Assuming without deciding that Auten has preserved this matter for our review,[15] we hold this argument does not support a finding of reversible error.Â  Any failure by the trial court to make the desired finding did not inure to Autenâ€™s prejudice.Â  Indeed, Autenâ€™s insistence that the separation agreement is unambiguous would, if anything, bar consideration of parol evidence as to whether or not Parrish intended that the agreement would prevent Snipes from receiving his retirement funds as the named beneficiary on the account.[16]Â  
3.Â  Auten further argues the trial court erred in interpreting the word â€œkeep,â€ alleging that, in the appealed order, the definition of the term appearing in the sixth edition of Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary was selectively edited to fit Snipesâ€™s desired interpretation of the agreement.Â  We disagree.
The definition quoted by the trial court excluded the phrases â€œto continueâ€ and â€œnot to lose or part with.â€Â  Notwithstanding these omissions, we hold the trial court did not interpret the quoted part of the definition out of context.[17]Â  Rather, it appears the trial court was following the well-established principle that alienability is an intrinsic attribute of ownership.[18]Â  Undue emphasis on the excluded portion of the definition would have the undesirable effect of compromising what was and should have been Parrishâ€™s unfettered right to dispose of his property as he wished.Â  This right included the option of retaining Snipes as the beneficiary of his retirement funds upon his death.
4.Â  Finally, we reject Autenâ€™s suggestion that Snipesâ€™s failure to testify or introduce evidence warrants a finding that she had no expectancy interest in the Signator account.Â  The focus of this controversy is Parrishâ€™s intent with respect to his retirement funds.Â  In any event, it is evident from the pleadings that Snipes herself contacted Signator Investments after Parrishâ€™s death for payment of his retirement account proceeds; therefore, it would appear that she had reason to believe she had a valid claim to the funds.
 AFFIRMED.
 BEATTY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The divorce decree provided the â€œseparation agreement entered into between the parties . . . shall survive in this judgment of divorce by reference but not be merged and that the parties are hereby ordered and directed to comply with each and every provision of said agreement.â€
[3]Â  McDuffie v. McDuffie, 313 S.C. 397, 399, 438 S.E.2d 239, 241 (1993).Â  
[4]Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 623, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302-03 (2001). 
[5]Â  Pearson v. Church of God, 325 S.C. 45, 54, 478 S.E.2d 849, 853 (1996). 
[6] Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 340, 491 S.E.2d 583, 589 (Ct. App. 1997).
[7]Â  Stribling v. Stribling, 369 S.C. 400, ___, 632 S.E.2d 291, 293 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Estate of Revis v. Revis, 326 S.C. 470, 477, 484 S.E.2d 112, 116 (Ct. App. 1997)).
[8]Â  Estate of Revis v. Revis, 326 S.C. 470, 478, 484 S.E.2d 112, 116 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Although Revis concerned a beneficiary interest in a life insurance policy rather than a retirement account, the two are analogous in that â€œ[l]ike the beneficiary in a life insurance policy, the IRA beneficiary merely has an expectancy interest in the IRA until the ownerâ€™s death.â€Â  Stribling, 369 S.C. at ___, 632 S.E.2d at 294. Â 
[9]Â  Stribling, 369 S.C. at ___, 632 S.E.2d at 294 (emphasis added). Â Â Â Â 
[10] In her brief, Auten argues the last paragraph of the agreement operated as a waiver of Snipesâ€™s beneficiary interest in the Signator account.Â  We disagree.Â  This paragraph provides that â€œeach party does hereby release and relinquish unto the other all of his or her rights, title, claim, interest and demand, rights of dower in and to the property of the other, whether now in being or hereinafter acquired.â€Â  Contrary to what Auten suggests, the phrase â€œwhether now in being or hereinafter acquiredâ€ refers to property that Parrish or Snipes might receive after executing the agreement, not to after-acquired rights that either could obtain in the otherâ€™s assets.
[11] We further disagree with Auten that the release language at issue here is sufficiently similar to that in Estate of Altobelli v. International Business Machines, 77 F.3d 78 (4th Cir. 1996), so as to warrant a finding that it amounted to a relinquishment of Snipesâ€™s right as the named beneficiary on the Signator account.Â  The parties to the separation agreement in Altobelli, expressly â€œwaive[d] and transfer[red]â€ to each other â€œany interestâ€ each had in certain accounts awarded to the other spouse.Â  Id. at 80.Â  This language is more specific than the general release paragraph in the separation agreement between Parrish and Snipes.
[12] See Estate of Revis, 326 S.C. at 479, 484 S.E.2d at 117 (suggesting one year to be a reasonable time for an insured to make a change in beneficiaries) (citing Aetna Life Ins. Co. v. Wadsworth, 689 P.2d 46 (Wash. 1984)). 
[13] The reasons Auten cited were (1) the divorce, (2) Snipesâ€™s remarriage soon after, and (3) Parrishâ€™s terminal illness.
[14] See Snakenberg v. Hartford Cas. Ins. Co., 299 S.C. 164, 172-73, 383 S.E.2d 2, 7 (Ct. App. 1989) (distinguishing motive from intent and stating that, whereas motive â€œis the actorâ€™s subjective reason for doing the act,â€ intent â€œis proved by showing that the actor acted willingly (volition) and that he knew or should have known the result would follow from his actâ€).
[15] The record does not indicate Auten moved under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment on the ground that the trial court failed to make a specific finding that the separation agreement was unambiguous.Â  See Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (stating an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal but must have been raised to and ruled on by the trial court); Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C.497, 501-02, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding an issue is not preserved when the trial court does not explicitly rule on it and the appellant does not move to alter or amend the judgment on that ground).
[16] See Estate of Revis, 326 S.C. at 478, 484 S.E.2d at 116 (â€œWhere a property settlement agreement is ambiguous, the court may consider parol evidence to ascertain the intent of the parties.â€).Â  We further note that Rushton v. Lott, 330 S.C. 418, 499 S.E.2d 222 (Ct. App. 1998), which Auten cites in her brief, is of questionable applicability to this case.Â  In Rushton, extrinsic evidence in the form of a letter was admitted as evidence that the parties to the separation agreement at issue had intended to divest the husbandâ€™s beneficiary interest in a particular asset.Â  Id. at 421, 499 S.E.2d at 224.
[17] In the appealed order, the trial court stated as follows:Â  â€œThe word â€˜keep,â€™ in its plain and ordinary meaning, means to â€˜have or retain in oneâ€™s own power or possession; . . . ; to preserve or retain; to maintain, carry on, conduct, or manage.â€ (Ellipses in original.)
[18] Cf. Alderman v. Alderman, 178 S.C. 9, 44, 181 S.E.2d 897, 911 (1935) (â€œOne of the main incidents of property is its transferability. The power of disposing of stock, like the power of disposing of any other property, is a common right, and necessarily attaches to ownership.â€) (quoting 7 Rul. Case L. Corporations Â§ 239, at 261 (1929)).

title: Evans v. Stewart and Cusack
description: In this tort action, James F. Evans sued Blake C. Stewart and Blakeâ€™s mother, Melony A. Cusack, seeking damages arising from an automobile accident in which  Evans was a passenger in a car driven by Stewart. Evans appeals from the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Cusack finding there was no basis to support Cusackâ€™s liability under the family purpose doctrine.
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James F. Evans, Appellant,
v.
Blake C. Stewart and Melony A. Cusack, Defendants,
Of whom Melony A. Cusack is the, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4161
Formerly Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-306
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed July 5, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Daryl J. Corbin, of Florence, for Appellant.
 Robert J. Thomas and William H. Bowman, III, of Columbia, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â In this tort action, James F. Evans appeals from the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Melony A. Cusack under the family purpose doctrine.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Evans brought this action against Blake C. Stewart and Blakeâ€™s mother, Cusack, seeking damages arising from an automobile accident.Â  Evans was a passenger in a car driven by Stewart when Stewart fell asleep at the wheel, causing a head-on collision with another car.Â  At the time of the accident, Stewart, Evans and another friend were returning from a two day trip to the beach for spring break.Â  Evans filed a complaint against Stewart and Cusack seeking damages from Stewart based on Stewartâ€™s negligence and damages from Cusack based on the family purpose doctrine and negligent entrustment.Â  Cusack moved for summary judgment asserting there was no genuine issue of material fact and she was entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  
At a hearing on the matter, the parties submitted the deposition of Stewart.Â  Stewart testified that at the time of the accident, he was eighteen years old and had moved out of his motherâ€™s home two to three months prior to the accident.Â  Stewart was working full time and was sharing a house with two roommates, paying approximately $150 a month in rent.Â  He was entirely self-supporting.Â  Stewart had moved out of his motherâ€™s home because he could not get along with his stepfather.Â  Although he did move back in with his mother following the accident because he needed someone to take care of him, it was not his intention to return to her home after he moved.Â  The truck Stewart was driving at the time of the accident was purchased by Stewart for a total of $1,200, with $1,000 from money he had in savings and $200 from his stepfather.Â  Because Stewart was only seventeen at the time of purchase, the car was registered in Cusackâ€™s name.Â  Cusack also paid Stewartâ€™s insurance until Stewart â€œcould get on [his] feet.â€Â  Stewart testified he drove the truck mostly and considered it his truck, and that he paid for gas and the maintenance of the truck.Â  The truck stayed in Stewartâ€™s possession, he drove it to and from work, and he used it for recreational purposes.Â  When the accident occurred, Stewart did not feel he needed to ask his motherâ€™s permission to take the vehicle to the beach, and she did not know that he had gone on the trip.Â  
Additionally, Cusack submitted her affidavit in which she swore, although the truck in question was titled in her name, she was not the true owner; that she and her husband gave Stewart $200 toward the purchase of the automobile but that Stewart used $1,000 of his own money to buy the truck; Stewart was still a minor at the time of purchase and the truck was therefore registered in her name; Stewart was responsible for all costs and expenses involved in operating the truck; Stewart was the sole user of the truck and he kept it for his own pleasure and convenience; and at the time of the accident, she had no control over Stewartâ€™s use of the truck and had no knowledge of his trip to the beach.Â  
The trial judge noted that Stewart did not live with Cusack, he was self-supporting, the truck was kept at Stewartâ€™s residence and was in his sole possession, Stewart paid the insurance, maintenance and gas for the vehicle, and at the time of the accident, Stewart was on his way back from a beach trip of which Cusack had no knowledge.Â  He found Evans had not presented any evidence to contradict the testimony of Stewart or the affidavit of Cusack, and thus found there was no basis to support Cusackâ€™s liability under the family purpose doctrine and Cusack was entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  He further determined there was no basis to support a claim for negligent entrustment as there was no evidence Cusack had control over the truck, nor any evidence that Stewart was addicted to intoxicants or had the habit of drinking or drove while intoxicated.Â  Accordingly, he also found Cusack was entitled to summary judgment on the negligent entrustment cause of action as well.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  â€œA motion for summary judgment shall be granted â€˜if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€™â€Â 
Id. Â (quoting Rule 56(c), SCRCP). When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP. Â Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  In determining whether a genuine issue of fact exists, the evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003).Â  It is not sufficient for one to create an inference that is not reasonable or an issue of fact that is not genuine.Â  Durkin v. Hansen, 313 S.C. 343, 346, 437 S.E.2d 550, 552 (Ct. App. 1993). Â Although summary judgment is a drastic remedy which should be cautiously invoked, where a verdict is not reasonably possible under the facts presented, summary judgment is proper.Â  Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 425, 529 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2000).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Evans contends the trial judge erred in granting summary judgment to Cusack under the family purpose doctrine.Â  He asserts there were genuine issues of fact in dispute relating to ownership, control, and use of the vehicle such that summary judgment was inappropriate.Â  We disagree.
â€œUnder the family purpose doctrine, the head of a family who owns, furnishes, and maintains a vehicle for the general use and convenience of his family is liable for the negligence of a family member having general authority to operate the vehicle for such a purpose.â€Â  Thompson v. Michael, 315 S.C. 268, 272, 433 S.E.2d 853, 855 (1993).Â  The doctrine has its genesis in the law of agency, and it will impose liability on a parent when a child is acting as his agent.Â  Id.Â  Thus, â€œone â€˜who has made it his business to furnish a car for the use of his family is liable as principal or master when such business is being carried out by a family member using the vehicle for its intended purpose, the family member thereby filling the role of agent or servant.â€™â€Â  Campbell v. Paschal, 290 S.C. 1, 8, 347 S.E.2d 892, 897 (Ct. App. 1986) (quoting 8 A.L.R.3d 1191 at 1196 (1966)).Â  Even if a parent owns the car, it must be determined whether the parent provided the car for the general use and convenience of the family, and if the car was not provided for the general use and convenience of the family, there is no relationship of principal and agent at the time of the wreck to impose liability on the parent.Â  Thompson, 315 S.C. at 273, 433 S.E.2d at 855.Â  Further, while the applicability of the family purpose doctrine is ordinarily a question of fact for the jury, where no factual issue is created the question becomes one of law, properly decided by the trial judge.Â  Lucht v. Youngblood, 266 S.C. 127, 133, 221 S.E.2d 854, 857 (1976). 
Evans points to Stewartâ€™s deposition testimony in arguing genuine issues of fact exist. He asserts Stewart testified that while he drove the truck, it was titled in Cusackâ€™s name, and Stewart received no insurance proceeds from the loss of the vehicle.Â  He also notes Stewart stated that Cusack could have driven the truck if she wanted to and she controlled who drove the truck, and that if Cusack had needed the truck to haul something somewhere, she could have used it.Â  Finally, he asserts Stewartâ€™s testimony that Cusack had instructed him to bring the truck back to her once or twice while he lived away from home was evidence of her continued control of the use of the truck after he moved out of her home.Â  
A review of Stewartâ€™s deposition reveals that, while the truck was titled in Cusackâ€™s name, Stewart provided the bulk of the funds to purchase the vehicle, he paid for the maintenance of the vehicle, the truck was titled in his motherâ€™s name merely because Stewart was a minor at the time of purchase, and Stewart considered the truck to be his.Â  As to insurance proceeds from the totaled truck, while Stewart testified he did not receive anything for it, neither did he know if his mother received anything for it.Â  Stewartâ€™s testimony regarding the use of the truck by others reveals only that Cusack or her husband would have been allowed to use the truck if they had the need, as Stewart, â€œwouldnâ€™t tell [his] mom she couldnâ€™t use the truck,â€ and would not tell his stepfather he could not use the truck because he â€œrespect[ed] him too.â€Â  Finally, concerning Cusackâ€™s directive that he return the truck to her home after Stewart moved out, the deposition testimony shows only that â€œmaybe once or twiceâ€ Cusack instructed Stewart to bring the vehicle back to her when the two had argued, however, the truck was not in fact taken to Cusack on those occasions, but remained in Stewartâ€™s possession.Â  
Even if we were to assume Cusack â€œownedâ€ the vehicle since it was titled in her name, ownership alone is insufficient. There must also be evidence Cusack furnished and maintained the vehicle for the general use and convenience of her family.Â  If the car was not provided for the general use and convenience of her family, there is no relationship of principal and agent at the time of the wreck to impose liability on Cusack.Â  Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Evans, there is simply no evidence Cusack furnished and maintained the truck for the general use and convenience of her family such that she is liable as principal or master for Stewartâ€™s use of the vehicle as her agent or servant.Â Â  
For the foregoing reasons, the order granting Cusack summary judgment is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
