title: Reed-Richards v. Clemson University
description: This appeal concerns whether a workers' compensation claimant is entitled to lifetime benefits because of a workplace injury resulting in a diagnosis of incomplete paraplegia.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Susan Reed-Richards, Respondent,
v.
Clemson University, Employer and State Accident Fund, Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4162
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Cynthia B. Polk, State Accident Fund, of Columbia, Terry M. Mauldin, of Lexington, Thomas Carl Cofield, of Lexington, for Appellants.
Bryan D. Ramey, of Piedmont, John S. Nichols , of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This is a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  Clemson University, the employer, and the State Accident Fund, the carrier,[1] appeal the award of lifetime benefits to Susan Reed-Richards.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On November 13, 2000, Reed-Richards sustained an injury arising out of the scope of her employment as an administrative assistant at Clemson University.Â  She sought lifetime medical care and weekly compensation benefits for life.Â  Appellants denied Reed-Richards had become a paraplegic as a result of the accident and sought to limit her benefits to the normal statutory maximum of 500 weeks.
In 1973, Reed-Richards had sustained a compression fracture of her spine at the T-11/T-12 vertebrae level as the result of a motor vehicle accident.Â  She did relatively well after the accident until 1978, when she developed difficulty with bladder control and walking. 
In 1979, Reed-Richards had surgery for a posterior fusion and the placement of Harrington rods in her spine.Â  She did well after this procedure until 1993, when she began having some bladder leakage at night.Â  In 1994, she underwent additional surgery, which included removal of the Harrington rods and â€œan anterior two-level corpectomy with strutting and fusion with plate.â€Â  Shortly after these procedures, she lost control of her bowel and bladder and developed urinary retention.Â  Because of increasing pain and bowel and bladder difficulties, she had still more surgery in 1995, after which she was able to control her bowel functions. Â Â 
On August 14, 2000, Reed-Richards began working for Clemson University, performing clerical work.Â  Approximately three months later, on November 13, 2000, she fell after catching her leg on an open file drawer. 
As a result of the accident, Reed-Richards has to use a walker, something she never needed before.Â  She has also lost the ability to control her bowels; they empty at random times, forcing her to wear adult diapers and restricting her from going out in public because of odor problems.Â  Her bladder condition originating from her 1973 accident has worsened, requiring her to catheterize herself more often than she had to in the past.Â  Because of these problems, she is able to perform only menial tasks and cannot pursue additional vocational training.Â  In addition, she has had to take medications for anxiety, pain, and leg spasms.
After a hearing on April 17, 2002, the single commissioner issued an order finding Reed-Richards totally and permanently disabled, but limited her benefits to 500 weeks.Â  Reed-Richards appealed to the full commission, alleging she was entitled to lifetime benefits.Â  The full commission vacated the single commissionerâ€™s order and remanded the matter for a de novo hearing. 
On remand, the single commissioner held a hearing on April 8, 2003.Â  On September 16, 2003, the single commissioner issued an order finding Reed-Richards was a paraplegic as a result of the accident and therefore entitled to lifetime benefits.Â  This finding was based in large part on the deposition and notes of Dr. David Shallcross, one of Reed-Richards treating physicians, who on March 21, 2003, wrote a letter stating in pertinent part as follows:

This patient has an incomplete paraplegia (is a paraplegic). â€˜Paraplegiaâ€™, according to the International Standards of Neurologic Classification of Spinal Cord Injury, Revised Sixth Edition, dated 2000, is â€˜impairment or loss of motor and/or sensory function in the thoracic, lumbar, or sacral segments of the spinal cord secondary to damage of neural elements within the spinal
canal.â€™
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

By order dated May 27, 2004, an appellate panel of the full commission upheld the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  Appellants sought judicial review in the circuit court, which issued an order dated August 15, 2002, affirming the full commission.
DISCUSSION
1.Â  Appellants contend the circuit court erred in affirming the finding that Reed-Richards was a paraplegic and therefore entitled to lifetime workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  We disagree.Â  
The right of an injured worker to obtain lifetime workersâ€™ compensation benefits is controlled by South Carolina Code section 42-9-10.Â  This section provides in pertinent part as follows:

Notwithstanding the five hundred week limitation prescribed in this section or elsewhere in this title, any person determined to be totally and permanently disabled who as a result of a compensable injury is a paraplegic, a quadriplegic, or who has suffered physical brain damage is not subject to the five hundred week limitation and shall receive the benefits for life.[3]

We understand Appellantsâ€™ arguments to be as follows:Â  (1) the circuit court erred in determining that, because the statute did not differentiate between complete and incomplete paraplegia, the legislature would have to make that distinction; (2) had the legislature intended to include incomplete paraplegia as a condition under which a claimant was eligible for lifetime benefits, it could have done so; (3) a holding that incomplete paraplegia can entitle a claimant to lifetime benefits would lead to an absurdly inconsistent result when considered with other workersâ€™ compensation statutes that set out a compensation scheme distinguishing between total loss and less than total loss; (4) it was improper to rely on both a medical text and a common usage dictionary to determine that the term â€œparaplegicâ€ could include a diagnosis of incomplete paraplegia; and (5) the â€œliberal purposeâ€ of the workersâ€™ compensation legislation â€œis not an unbridled fiat to engage in judicial legislation in violation of the separation of powers.â€[4]  
We do not fault the workersâ€™ compensation commission or the circuit court for relying on both a medical text and a common usage dictionary in determining that the term â€œparaplegicâ€ could embrace one diagnosed with â€œincomplete paraplegiaâ€ as opposed to â€œcomplete paraplegia.â€[5]Â  
First, Dr. Shallcross expressly stated, albeit parenthetically, that Reed-Richards â€œis a paraplegic,â€ thus implying she was eligible for lifetime benefits under section 42-9-10.Â  It was reasonable for the commission to consider the authority on which he based this pronouncement.[6]
Second, as the circuit court aptly noted, the only alternative definition offered by Appellants was their counselâ€™s â€œlay personâ€™s definitionâ€ that â€œyou have total and full and complete loss of use of your lower extremities.â€Â  We agree with Reed-Richards and the circuit court that this definition is not evidence at all, let alone substantial evidence upon which to base a reversal of the commission.[7]Â  Moreover, we are unaware of any legal authority restricting â€œplain and ordinaryâ€ meanings to commonly held stereotypes of the terms they describe.
We therefore hold the commission and the circuit court correctly interpreted the term â€œparaplegicâ€ to include a diagnosis of incomplete paraplegia.Â  This interpretation, though consistent with the legislative purpose of construing workersâ€™ compensation laws in favor of claimants,[8] does not rise to the level of judicial legislation.Â  There was no need for the legislature to specify that a claimant can recover lifetime benefits based on a diagnosis of incomplete paraplegia if the claimant is totally and permanently disabled as a result of this condition.Â  
2.Â  We do not address Appellantsâ€™ contention that the interpretation of the term â€œparaplegicâ€ endorsed by both the commission and the circuit court cannot be logically reconciled with other statutes within the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act that set forth a partial loss ratio scheme on which statutory benefits are based.Â  There is no explicit ruling on this argument by the single commissioner, full commission, or the circuit court, and the record does not indicate Appellants raised this omission in any post-trial motion; therefore, we cannot address it in this appeal.[9]
3.Â  Appellants further challenge the finding that Reed-Richards was a paraplegic under section 42-9-10 as a result of the accident on November 13, 2000.Â  We hold there is substantial evidence on the record as a whole to support this finding.[10]Â  
Appellants correctly note that, before the November 2000 injury, Reed-Richards had a seventeen-year history of back and spinal problems that included pain, bladder and bowel incontinence, and ambulatory difficulties.Â  They also point to Dr. Shallcrossâ€™s description on July 30, 2001, of Reed-Richardsâ€™s injury as â€œincomplete paraplegia due to T-12 fracture,â€ and there is no dispute that she had suffered a T-11/T-12 vertebrae fracture in 1973.Â  Nevertheless, before the November 2000 accident, Reed-Richards had never been diagnosed with paraplegia and was able to work full time, including overtime.Â  Although she had experienced numbness in her right leg before her on-the-job injury, there is no evidence that she ever had a problem with both legs before this accident.Â  Likewise, although she had temporary bowel problems in the past, she did not have any trouble controlling her bowels from the time she began working for Clemson until her injury several months later.Â  The change in her bowel condition is significant because, as Dr. Shallcross testified, the loss of control of her anal sphincter, as evidenced in an anal EMG, further convinced him that her complaints were genuine.
Dr. Shallcross further stated that â€œbased on the fact that [Reed-Richards] was fully ambulatory without any assisted device prior to the injury and based on the fact that she was not suffering from fecal incontinence prior to that injury, her inability to work is pretty much all related to the workersâ€™ comp injury.â€Â  Significantly, when asked specifically about the cause of her present symptoms, Dr. Shallcross responded that Reed-Richards â€œhad a pre-existing injury to the lower part of her spinal cord which was made worse by her workersâ€™ comp injury.â€Â  (Emphasis added).[11]
Based on the foregoing, we hold the record in this case has substantial evidence to support the commissionâ€™s finding that, pursuant to section 42-9-10, Reed-Richards became totally and permanently disabled as a result of the accident on November 13, 2000.
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Clemson University and the State Accident Fund will also be collectively referred to as â€œAppellants.â€
[2]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-10 (1985 & Supp. 2005).
[4]Â  See Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 498, 541 S.E.2d 526, 531 (2001) (noting that even a liberal construction of workersâ€™ compensation statutes â€œ â€˜does not authorize the amendment, alteration or extension of its provision beyond its obvious meaningâ€™ â€) (quoting Gajam v. Bradlick Co., 355 S.E.2d 899, 902 (Va. Ct. App. 1987)).
[5]Â  The commission cited the 2000 edition of the International Standards of Neurological Classification of Spinal Cord Injury, to which Dr. Shallcross referred in explaining his diagnosis, and Websterâ€™s Ninth Collegiate Dictionary for the â€œplain and ordinary meaning of â€˜paraplegia.â€™ â€
[6]Â  As noted earlier in this opinion, Dr. Shallcross stated in his letter that the International Standards of Neurological Classification of Spinal Cord Injury defines paraplegia â€œas impairment or loss of motor and/or sensory function in the thoracic, lumbar, or sacral segments of the spinal cord secondary to damage of neural elements within the spinal canal.â€Â  (Emphasis added.)
[7]Â  See Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 64, 624 S.E.2d 649, 653 (2000) (â€œIt is well established that counselâ€™s statements regarding the facts of a case and counselâ€™s arguments are not admissible evidence.â€).
[8]Â  See Lizee v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 367 S.C. 122, 130 n.2, 623 S.E.2d 860, 864 n.2 (Ct. App. 2005) (noting â€œthe principle that workersâ€™ compensation laws in general . . . are to be liberally construed in favor of claimants and coverageâ€).
[9] Â See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (finding an issue was not preserved for appellate review when the trial court did not explicitly rule on the appellantâ€™s argument); United Dominion Realty Trust v. Wal-Mart Stores, 307 S.C. 102, 107, 413 S.E.2d 866, 869 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding that, when the circuit court sitting in an appellate capacity does not address an issue and the appellant fails to move to alter or amend on that ground, the alleged error is not preserved for further appellate review).
[10] See Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999) (â€œThe possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent the Commissionâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€). 
[11] The contention that the November 2000 accident alone would not have caused Reed-Richardsâ€™s present condition is no reason for Appellants to disclaim liability. Â See Brown v. R.L. Jordan Oil Co., 291 S.C. 272, 275, 353 S.E.2d 280, 282 (1987) (â€œIt is no defense that the accident, standing alone, would not have caused the claimantâ€™s condition, because the employer takes the employee as he finds him.â€).Â  Likewise, a showing that the accident resulted only in the exacerbation of existing problems would not preclude recovery.Â  See Mullinax v. Winn-Dixie Stores, 318 S.C. 431, 437, 458 S.E.2d 76, 80 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œA condition is compensable unless it is due solely to the natural progression of a pre-existing condition.â€).

title: Walsh v. Woods
description: This appeal concerns whether Wife II may be awarded surviving spouse benefits through her deceased husbandâ€™s retirement plan, even though Husbandâ€™s attempt to change the beneficiary of his benefits to Wife II did not become legally effective and Wife II did not marry Husband until after he retired.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Frances Walsh, as personal representative of the estate of Jerome Walsh, deceased, and in her individual capacity,
Appellant,
v.
Joyce K. Woods, f/k/a Joyce K. Walsh, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

AFFIRMED 

Opinion No. 4163
Heard May 11, 2006 â€“ Filed October 16, 2006


  
    
      
Russell H. Putnam, Jr., of Hinesville, Georgia, for Appellant.
John S. Nichols and Kelli Lister Sullivan, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J:Â  Frances Walsh (Wife II), individually and in her capacity as personal representative of the estate of her deceased husband, Jerome J. Walsh (Husband), brought this action against Husbandâ€™s former wife, Joyce K. Woods (Wife I), seeking relief pertaining to the disposition of surviving spouse benefits (SSB) made available through Husbandâ€™s retirement plan.Â  Wife II appeals the trial courtâ€™s order granting Wife Iâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
We note at the commencement that although some changes and additions have been made, the facts largely mirror those in Walsh v. Woods, 358 S.C. 259, 594 S.E.2d 548 (Ct. App. 2004), revâ€™d Walsh v. Woods, Mem. Op. No. 2005-MO-043 (S.C.Sup.Ct. filed Sept. 19, 2005).Â  Husband married Wife I in 1957, and they separated in 1970.Â  Although Husband and Wife I lived apart, they remained married for twenty years after their separation.Â  In 1980, Husband met Wife II and they began dating.Â  In 1989, after forty years of employment at E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. (DuPont), Husband retired. Â During his tenure at DuPont, Husband participated in a joint and survivor annuity plan governed by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).Â  When he retired, Husband signed a Post Retirement Company-Paid Survivor Benefits and Spouse Benefit Option designating Wife I, to whom he was still married, as the beneficiary of his SSB plan in the event he predeceased her.Â  
On August 24, 1990, Husband and Wife I divorced.Â  Incident to the divorce, they entered into an agreement which the family court approved, adopted, and incorporated into the divorce decree.Â  The decree provided, in relevant part:

[T]he parties shall sign whatever documents or other paperwork that is necessary to enforce this Agreement.Â  I find that the parties have further agreed that each shall retain what .Â  .Â  . retirement plans, pension plans .Â  .Â  . etc., that he or she has in his or her possession.Â  If the wife is required to sign any papers concerning the husbandâ€™s retirement or benefit options from DuPont of Westinghouse, then she shall sign those. 

Husband never presented Wife I with any documents to sign regarding his retirement plan, and neither party obtained a Qualified Domestic Relations Order (QDRO) during Husbandâ€™s lifetime.Â  
On May 31, 1991, Husband wrote DuPont a letter informing the company that he had divorced Wife I and that his â€œex-wife has waived any claim to my pensions . . . and this has been documented as part of the divorce decree.â€Â  The letter further stated Husband wished to change his beneficiary to Wife II.Â  In 1994, Husband and Wife II married.Â  On November 30, 1994, Husband again wrote DuPont.Â  Apparently, Husband believed his first letter to DuPont sufficed to change the beneficiary of his planâ€™s SSB from Wife I to Wife II.Â  Accordingly, his second letter advised DuPont he wished to change the beneficiary from Frances Dudley to Frances Dudley Walsh, inasmuch as he had married Wife II.Â  Further, the letter stated â€œ[i]f this letter does not suffice [to change the beneficiary], please send me the necessary paperwork to have my wife eligible for . . . spouse benefits.â€Â  Despite the two letters to DuPont, the change Husband requested was never made legally effective.Â  
On January 27, 1996, Husband died. Â His will named Wife II as the sole beneficiary and the personal representative of his estate.Â  After Husbandâ€™s death, DuPont began paying benefits to Wife I.Â  In 1997, Wife II filed suit against DuPont, which was removed to federal court, seeking a judicial determination that the SSB should be paid to her rather than Wife I.Â  DuPont successfully moved for summary judgment on the grounds no QDRO existed terminating Wife Iâ€™s right to receive benefits at the time of Husbandâ€™s retirement.Â  
Wife II then contacted John W. Harte, the attorney who represented Husband in his divorce from Wife I, and requested he prepare and submit a QDRO to DuPont.Â  Harte prepared the QDRO, then contacted Vickie Johnson, the attorney who represented Wife I in the divorce action, and requested she obtain Wife Iâ€™s signature on the document.Â  Wife I did not sign the QDRO, but authorized Johnson to sign it on her behalf.Â  Wife I noted on the document, however, that she authorized her signature under protest and out of concern she would be held in contempt of court if she refused to sign.Â  
After Harte submitted the QDRO to DuPont, he received a letter from the company advising him that the document was not valid because it did not comply with the mandates of the Internal Revenue Code.Â  Further, the letter stated that â€œ[a] QDRO cannot be entered after the death of the participant. Â A participant must be a living person.Â  There was no QDRO in effect at the participantâ€™s death that awarded any benefits to an alternate payee.Â  Therefore, there are no benefits payable pursuant to a QDRO.â€Â  In addition, DuPontâ€™s letter advised that even if the document had been prepared at some point after his retirement, but prior to Husbandâ€™s death, it would nonetheless be ineffective to divest Wife I of her SSB because Wife I owned thoseÂ  benefits which vested upon Husbandâ€™s retirement.Â  
When DuPont refused to pay the SSB to Wife II, she commenced an action to recover all monies past, present and future paid to Wife I.Â  Her suit, filed in the Court of Common Pleas for Richland County, was subsequently removed to the United State District Court for the District of South Carolina.Â  DuPont then successfully moved for summary judgment.Â  
On December 18, 2000, Wife II filed the instant action against Wife I seeking recovery under the following seven legal and equitable theories:Â  (1) unjust enrichment; (2) â€œlaw of the case;â€ (3) res judicata; (4) collateral estoppel; (5) breach of contract; (6) bad faith breach of contract; and (7) conversion.Â  Wife I answered, denying Wife II was entitled to the relief sought in her complaint, and asserted as defenses: (1) expiration of the statute of limitations; (2) failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted; (3) laches; and (4) res
judicata.  
The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.Â  Wife I argued, inter alia, that all of Wife IIâ€™s causes of action failed because the SSB vested in Wife I in 1989, at the time of Husbandâ€™s retirement, and could not now be divested.Â  Wife I further asserted the applicable statute of limitations barred Wife IIâ€™s claims.Â  In support of her cross motion, Wife II asserted no genuine issues of material fact existed that Wife I had waived her rights to the benefits in the divorce proceeding.Â  In addition, Wife II asserted that the trial court could enforce the property settlement agreement by requiring Wife I to disgorge herself of all SSB payments she had received in the past and will receive in the future by transferring the payments to Wife II.
The trial court, relying on Hopkins v. AT& T, 105 F.3d 153, 157 (4th Cir. 1997), granted Wife Iâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Under Hopkins, the trial court reasoned that (1) SSB vests in a plan participantâ€™s current spouse on the date the participant retires, whether or not spouses are married at the time the participant dies, and (2) surviving spouse benefits may not be paid to a spouse who marries a participant after the participantâ€™s retirement. Â The trial court expressly determined the holding in Hopkins was determinative of the entire case and, therefore, declined to address Wife Iâ€™s other grounds for summary judgment and further declined to reach Wife IIâ€™s cross motion for summary judgment.Â  
Wife II appealed, and this court reversed, finding the trial court erred in determining Hopkins was dispositive of all of the issues on appeal because given the facts, the case of Estate of Altobelli v. International Business Machines Corporation, 77 F.3d 78 (4th Cir. 1996), also applied.Â  Further, we found the trial court erred in reasoning that ERISA governed the disposition of all of Wife IIâ€™s legal and equitable claims.Â  Wife I petitioned for rehearing on the grounds that the statute of limitations barred Wife IIâ€™s claims.Â  We withdrew our opinion reversing the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment and affirmed the trial court based on the statute of limitations.Â  The Supreme Court reversed, finding the statute of limitations did not bar Wife IIâ€™s claims and remanded the case to this court to determine whether the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to Wife I.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, appellate courts apply the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, which states that summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Willis v. Wu, 362 S.C. 146, 150-51, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004); see also, Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 316-17, 592 S.E.2d 326, 330 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating all ambiguities,
conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party).
Summary judgment is not appropriate when further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law. Â Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005); Montgomery v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 529, 542, 608 S.E.2d 440, 447 (Ct. App. 2004). Â Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them,
summary judgment should be denied. Â Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 5, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct. App. 2004). Â However, when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ,
summary judgment should be granted.Â Â  Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 821 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
As a threshold matter, we first turn our attention to Wife Iâ€™s assertion that Wife II failed to properly preserve the issue of whether her legal and equitable claims were barred by ERISA because the trial court expressly declined to rule on the issues.Â  Wife I argues because Wife II failed to make a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion requesting the trial court address such issues, she cannot argue them on appeal.Â  We disagree.
The trial court found Hopkins v. AT& T, 105 F.3d 153, 157 (4th Cir. 1997), barred Wife IIâ€™s claim and therefore, the court ruled that it was â€œunnecessary to reach Francesâ€™[s] cross motion for summary judgment.â€Â  In so ruling, the trial court adopted the analysis espoused by Hopkins and implicitly denied Wife IIâ€™s claims.Â  A Rule 59(e) motion is required to preserve issues that have not been ruled upon by the trial court.Â  See Wilder Corp v. Wilke, 330 S.C, 71, 77, 497 S.E.2d 731, 734 (1998) (noting that proper use of a Rule 59(e) motion is to preserve issues raised to but not ruled upon by the trial court). Â We hold that a motion under Rule 59(e) is unnecessary in this case because the trial courtâ€™s decision with respect to Wife IIâ€™s claims was clear.Â  These issues were clearly raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  Accordingly, Wife II was not required to move for relief under Rule 59(e) in order to preserve the issues for review. Â Finally, because, ERISA claims involve subject-matter jurisdiction, they may be raised at any time. Baker Hospital v. Isaac, 301 S.C. 248, 391 S.E.2d 549 (1990).
II.
Next, Wife II argues the trial court erred in granting Wife I summary judgment.Â  She premises her claim upon the proposition that by virtue of Wife Iâ€™s putative waiver of her rights to SSB, those benefits ipso facto became the property of Husband and thus passed to her under his will. Â We disagree.[1]
We begin our analysis by discussing the function of ERISA preemptionÂ  law in this case. Â In the case of Lewis v. Local 382, Intâ€™l Brotherhood of Elec. Workers (AFL-CIO), 335 S.C. 562, 569, 518 S.E.2d 583, 596 (1999), our Supreme Court addressed the issue of preemption under
ERISA:

Any and all State laws insofar as they relate to employee benefits plans are preempted by ERISA. 29 U.S.C.Â§1144(a); Duncan v. Provident Mut. Life Ins. Co. of Philadelphia, 310 S.C. 465. 427 S.E.2d 657 (1993). This Court has recognized that the pre-emptive effect of ERISA is a broad one. Baker Hosp. v Isaac, 301 S.C. 248, 391 S.E.2d 549 (1990). A state law â€œrelates toâ€ an ERISA-governed employee benefit plan, â€œif it has a connection with or reference to such a plan.â€ Shaw v. Delta air Lines, Inc., 463 U.S. 85, 90, 103 S. Ct. 2890, 2896, 77 L. Ed.2d 490 (1983). Â Further, a state law â€œrelates toâ€ an ERISA plan if the rights or restrictions it creates are predicated on the existence of such a plan. Ingersoll-Rand Co. v. McClendon, 498 U.S. 133, 111 S.Ct. 478, 112 L.Ed.2d 474 (1990). However, those state actions which affect employee benefits plans in â€œtoo tenuous, remote or peripheral a mannerâ€ do not relate to the plan. Shaw, 463 U.S. 85, 90. 

Here, it is inescapable that Wife IIâ€™s claim to the SSB, like the retirement benefits in Lewis, are predicated upon the existence of the husbandâ€™s pension plan. Â While ERISA related claims involve subject-matter jurisdiction, 29 U.S.C. Â§ 1132(3)(1) vests both state and federal courts with concurrent subject-matter jurisdiction of certain civil actions brought by participants or beneficiaries against an employee benefit plan. Â Nevertheless, under preemption principles, federal ERISA law must control our decision on the issue of Wife IIâ€™s claim to the SSB. Â See Baker Hosp. v. Isaac, 301 S.C. 248, 391 S.E.2d 549 (1990)(holding ERISA preempted a hospitalâ€™s contract, promissory estoppel, negligence, and misrepresentation claims); see also Dorn v. International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, et. al., 211 F.3d. 938 (5th Cir. 2000) (holding a state law claim by an ex-wife regarding her rights to receive benefits from an ERISA plan necessarily â€œrelates toâ€ an ERISA plan and preempts Louisiana law of conversion).
The trial court concluded the ERISA provisions, as interpreted in Hopkins, were dispositive of Wife IIâ€™s legal and equitable claims. Â On appeal, Wife II argues the case of Estate of Altobelli v. IBM Corp., 77 F.3d 78 (4th Cir. 1996) permits an ERISA participantâ€™s ex-spouse to waive, in a separate agreement, incorporated into a divorce decree, her interest as a beneficiary in her ex-husbandâ€™s pension plan.Â  
Altobelli analyzes the split among federal circuits on the issue of whether administrators of an ERISA plan are required to recognize a beneficiaryâ€™s waiver of his or her benefits. Â The majority of circuits that have addressed this issue have held such waivers are valid under certain circumstances. See Id.;
Mohamed v. Kerr, 53 F.3d 911 (8th Cir. 1995); Brandon v. Travelers Ins. Co., 18 F.3d 1321 (5th Cir. 1994); Metro. Life Ins. Co. v. Hanslip, 939 F.2d 904 (10th Cir. 1991); Fox Valley & Vicinity Constr. Workers Pension Fund v. Brown, 897 F.2d 275 (7th Cir. 1990) (en banc). Â Only two courts of appeals have disagreed, holding plan administrators need not look beyond the documents on file with the plan to determine whether there has been a valid waiver effectuated in outside private documents. Krishna v. Colgate Palmolive Co., 7 F.3d 11 (2nd Cir. 1993); McMillan v. Parrott, 913 F.2d 310 (6th Cir. 1990).Â  
In recognizing a split among the circuits, the Altobelli court followed the majority view and concluded that each of the parties in Altobelli â€œclearly intended to relinquish all interests in the pension plan of the other.â€Â  Id. at 81.Â  The court stated a beneficiary may waive pension benefits where the waiver specifically refers to and modifies the beneficiary interest, or through specific language in a divorce decree.Â  Id. at 81.Â  
The Altobelli court agreed with the Seventh Circuit that the anti-alienation clause does not apply to a beneficiaryâ€™s waiver.Â  According to the majority of federal courts, because ERISA does not explicitly address â€œwaiverâ€ by a beneficiary, the Fourth Circuit turned to federal common law to determine whether, and under what circumstances, an individual may validly waive her benefits in an ERISA plan. See Altobelli, 77 F.3d at 81. Â Under federal common law, an individualâ€™s waiver is valid if, â€œupon reading the language in the divorce decree, a reasonable person would have understood that she was waiving her beneficiary interest. . . .â€ Â Clift v. Clift, 210 F.3d 268, 271-72 (5th Cir. 2000); see also Mohamed, 53 F.3d at 914-15 (â€œa property settlement agreement entered into pursuant to a dissolution may divest former spouses of beneficiary rights in each otherâ€™s [ERISA benefits], if the agreement makes it clear that the former spouses so intend.â€). Moreover, â€œany waiver must be voluntarily made in good faith.â€ Clift, 210 F.3d at 272.
However, Altobelli arose out of facts clearly distinguishable from those in the instant case.Â  Altobelli dealt with a waiver of life insurance and pension plan benefits while the instant case deals with a waiver of SSB.Â  The Altobelli decision only holds that the ex-wife of Altobelli had validly waived her rights to his pension benefits pursuant to a QDRO. Â We observe also that Hopkins, consistent with Altobelli, held that as far as Mr. Hopkinsâ€™s pension benefits[2] were concerned, the first wife was entitled to them under the provisions of her QDRO. Â Hopkins, 105 F.3d at 155.Â  The court noted, however, that â€œ[b]enefits provided under a pension â€˜plan may not be assigned or alienated,â€™ 29 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1056(d)(1), except pursuant to a â€˜qualified domestic relations order.â€™â€ Â Id.Â  The court stated further that:

ERISA defines a â€œdomestic relations orderâ€ as any judgment, decree, or order which, â€œ(I) relates to the provision of child support, alimony payments, or marital property rights to a spouse, former spouse, child,Â  or other dependent of a participant, and (II) is made pursuant to a state domestic relations lawâ€¦.â€ 29 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1056(d)(3)(B)(ii). A domestic relationsÂ  order is â€œqualifiedâ€ if it, among other things, gives an alternate payee the right to â€œreceive all or a portion of the benefits payable to a participant under anÂ  planâ€¦.â€ 29 U.S.C.A Â§ 1056(d)(3)(B)(i)(I).
â€¦. AT&T contends that on the day Mr. Hopkins retired, the rights to Surviving Spouse Benefits vested in [Wife II), his current spouse. As a result, AT&T argues, the Surviving Spouse Benefits are no longer payable to a plan participant. Noting that a QDRO must relate to a benefit â€œpayable with respect to a participant.â€ 29 U.S.C.A. Â§
1056(d)(3)(B)(i)(I).

Id.Â 
The Hopkins court agreed with AT&Tâ€™s contention and held, as a matter of first impression in the federal courts, that Wife IIâ€™s rights to the SSB vested upon Mr. Hopkinsâ€™ retirement. Â Id.Â  Moreover, the court cited with approval the case of Anderson v. Marshall, 856 F. Supp. 604, 607 (D. Kan. 1994) for the proposition that â€œupon retirement, the Surviving Spouse Benefits â€˜became irrevocable and could not be changed [even by a] waiver of the designated beneficiary.â€™â€ See also, Rivers v. Central and South West Corporation, et al., 186 F.3d 681, 683-84 (5th Cir. 1999) (finding SSB irrevocably vested in plan participantâ€™s current wife â€œon the date of his retirement and [former wife] is forever barred from acquiring an interest in [his] pension planâ€).
In the present case, at the time Husband retired in 1989, the SSB vested in Wife I because the two were still married.Â  Although Husband had a ninety-day window prior to his retirement in which he could have, with Wife Iâ€™s written consent, removed her as a beneficiary of the SSB, this was not accomplished.Â  After Husband retired, even if Wife I had agreed to waive her SSB, she could not have done so under ERISA.Â  Wife Iâ€™s purported waiver in the divorce agreement was ineffective to waive the SSB because ERISA does not allow a beneficiary to waive SSB after a plan participant retires.
Moreover, even if Husband had divorced Wife I prior to retiring, or had never married Wife I to begin with, Wife IIâ€™s position with respect to the survivor benefits would be no different: Wife II would not be entitled to any SSB because she married Husband after he retired.Â  ERISA provides SSB â€œmay not be paid to a spouse who marries a participant after the participantâ€™s retirement.â€ Hopkins, 105 F.3d at 157 (citing 29 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1055(f)) (emphasis added).Â Â  
Therefore, because Wife Iâ€™s rights vested upon Husbandâ€™s retirement, those benefits belonged to her, not Husband. Â Under the terms of the property settlement agreement, each party was permitted to retain any pension plan in â€œhis or her possession.â€ Â Whether intended or not, the SSB were as much in Wife Iâ€™s â€œpossessionâ€ (control) as they could be. Â We agree with Wife I that even under the terms of the the partiesâ€™ property settlement agreement, she was entitled to retain her SSB because they were in her â€œpossessionâ€ at the time of the execution and approval by the court of the property settlement agreement. Â We therefore hold that Hopkins, not Altobelli is dispositive of the issues in this appeal.
It does seem untoward that Husband should not be able to have a component of his qualified joint and survivor annuity awarded to Wife II, rather than a woman from whom he was divorced and did not have a relationship with for years before his death. Â However, in keeping with our reading of federal law, there is no other resolution possible. 
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We find it difficult, as a practical matter, to imagine that such an arrangement could ever happen because as explained in Dorn v. Intâ€™l Brotherhood of Elec. Workers, et. al., 211 F.3d 938, 941 (5th Cir. 2000), an ERISA joint and survivor annuity is unlike a typical joint and survivor annuity â€œavailable in the commercial market, which commonly guarantees payment of a stipulated or determinable amount to two persons, frequently spouses, while both are living and after the death of either person, to whichever of the two survives.â€Â  In an ERISA annuity â€œ(1) the QJ&SAâ€™s (qualified joint and survivor annuity) annuity payments cease at the death of the participant spouse, regardless of whether his death occurs before or after the death of the non-participant spouse; and (2) if, but only if, the non-participant spouse survives the participant spouse does the survivorâ€™s annuity kick in.â€Â  Id. at 942.Â  
[2] The Hopkins court expresses in clear terms the operation ofÂ  a qualified joint and survivor annuity: â€œUnder the joint and survivor annuity, Mr. Hopkins receives a fixed income for life (pension benefits) and if his spouse survives him, she will receive 50% of the fixed income (Surviving Spouse Benefits) for the remainder of her life.â€Â  Hopkins, at 155.Â

title: Albertson v. Robinson
description: This appeal involves a claim of a fraudulent conveyance pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth, as codified in section 27-23-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).  The trial court found the challenged transfer of real property from Brian Robinson to his then wife, Maureen Robinson, was not a fraudulent transfer.  The judgment creditors appeal, and we reverse and remand.
text:
Albertson v. Robinson


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Nathan Albertson and Amanda Byfield-Albertson, Appellants,
v.
Brian William Robinson a/k/a Brian W. Robinson, Maureen Ann Robinson and American General Financial Services, Inc.,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Dorchester County
Â Patrick R. Watts, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 4164
Heard September 12, 2006 â€“ Filed October 16, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Robert A. Bernstein, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Christopher David Lizzi, of North Charleston, Maureen Ann Robinson, of Summerville and Thomas H. Brush, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This appeal involves a claim of a fraudulent conveyance pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth, as codified in section 27-23-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  The trial court found the challenged transfer of real property from Brian Robinson to his then wife, Maureen Robinson, was not a fraudulent transfer.Â  The judgment creditors appeal, and we reverse and remand. 
I.
Brian and Maureen Robinson were married on October 4, 1980.Â  The Robinsons experienced difficulties throughout their marriage resulting from Mr. Robinsonâ€™s abuse of alcohol.Â  These difficulties eventually led to the couplesâ€™ divorce on February 18, 2005.Â  
The property at issue in this case is the Robinsonsâ€™ former marital home, which was purchased on September 2, 1985.Â  During their marriage, the Robinsons conveyed an interest in the marital home several times between one another.Â  On June 2, 1992, Mr. Robinson conveyed his interest in the marital residence to Mrs. Robinson.Â  On February 28, 1996, Mrs. Robinson re-conveyed a one-half interest in the marital residence to Mr. Robinson.Â  The reason for the conveyances was Mr. Robinsonâ€™s alcoholism and Mrs. Robinsonâ€™s fears that this disease would ultimately harm the family.Â  
The underlying action arises from Mr. Robinsonâ€™s failure to complete work on a pool he contracted to build for Nathan and Amanda Albertson in August 2000.Â  At the time, Mr. Robinson was the sole proprietor of a business called Southeast Pool Specialties.Â  The contract price for the Albertsonsâ€™ pool was $16,995, and the Albertsons paid $11,895 as a down payment.Â  Mr. Robinson did not complete the construction of the pool.Â  He attributed his failure to complete the contract to his alcoholism.Â  
In February 2001, the Albertsons filed suit seeking damages for breach of contract.Â  Mr. Robinson did not respond to the lawsuit, but on June 15, 2001, Mrs. Robinson submitted a response to the court in the form of a letter to Mr. Albertson.Â  On September 25, 2001, an entry of default was lodged against Mr. Robinson.Â  As of September 2001, the Robinsonsâ€™ marital residence was titled jointly in their respective names.
On March 1, 2002, Mr. Robinson conveyed his one-half interest in the marital home to Mrs. Robinson.Â  The stated consideration for this conveyance was $5.00 and â€œlove and affection.â€Â  The Albertsons contend this conveyance should be found void as a fraudulent transfer because the transfer occurred after Mr. Robinson became indebted to them.Â  In this regard, the Albertsons assert the transfer by Mr. Robinson to Mrs. Robinson of his interest in the property was done with the purpose of avoiding payment of the debt.
On July 22, 2002, the court conducted a damages hearing in the underlying breach of contract action.Â  Mr. Robinson failed to appear for the hearing and judgment was entered against him on August 27, 2002, in the amount of $42,134.Â Â Â  
The Robinsons separated on June 16, 2003, and a Separation Agreement was finalized and entered on August 29, 2003.Â  The Robinsons were divorced on February 18, 2005.Â  
The Albertsons filed the present action in 2004.Â  The Albertsons sought a declaratory judgment and relief based on the claim that the March 1, 2002, transfer of Mr. Robinsonâ€™s interest in the property was void as a fraudulent transfer.
The trial court, following a hearing, denied the Albertsonsâ€™ Complaint for declaratory relief.Â  The trial court found that Mr. Robinson was not indebted to the Albertsons at the time of the March 1, 2002 transfer; there was no evidence Mr. Robinson failed to retain sufficient assets to pay the resulting judgment; the transfer was supported by adequate consideration; and there was no intent to defraud creditors with the transfer.
II.
A suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  An action to set aside a transfer as fraudulent pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth is an action in equity.Â  Future Group, II v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 97 n.6, 478 S.E.2d 45, 49 n.6 (1996).Â  This court therefore has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Pinckney v. Warren, 344 S.C. 382, 387, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001).Â  
III.
The Albertsons contend the March 1, 2002 conveyance between Mr. and Mrs. Robinson should be voided as a fraudulent transfer.Â  We agree.Â  
Though the Albertsons raise several arguments on appeal, this case is best dealt with by combining these arguments and examining the law concerning fraudulent transfers as a whole.Â Â  To do so, we first look to the statutes and case law concerning fraudulent transfers.Â  
The Statute of Elizabeth, as codified in section 27-23-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), governs fraudulent conveyances and provides in relevant part: 


  Every . . . conveyance of lands . . . which may be had or made to or for any intent or purpose to delay, hinder, or defraud creditors and others of their just and lawful . . . debts . . . must be deemed and taken . . . to be clearly and utterly void, frustrate and of no effect, any pretense, color, feigned consideration, expressing of use, or any other matter or thing to the contrary notwithstanding.

South Carolina courts have held that under the Statute of Elizabeth conveyances may be set aside under two conditions: first, where the transfer is made by the grantor with the actual intent of defrauding his creditors where that intent is imputable to the grantee, even though there is a valuable consideration; and, second, where a transfer is made without actual intent to defraud the grantorâ€™s creditors, but without valuable consideration. Â McDaniel v. Allen, 265 S.C. 237, 242-43, 217 S.E.2d 773, 775-76 (1975).Â  We dispose of this appeal pursuant to the latter situation.Â  We therefore do not reach the trial courtâ€™s finding that Mr. Robinson (in transferring his interest in the property) did not intend to defraud the Albertsons.Â  Cf. Royal Z Lanes, Inc. v. Collins Holding Corp., 337 S.C. 592, 596, 524 S.E.2d 621, 623 (1999) (stating grossly inadequate consideration for a conveyance is a â€œbadge of fraudâ€ and creates a rebuttable presumption of intent to defraud).Â  
We thus begin our examination with a determination of whether the challenged conveyance was supported by valuable consideration.Â  We find the record compels a finding that the transfer in question was not supported by valuable consideration.Â  
The record yields but one reasonable inferenceâ€”the transfer from Mr. Robinson to Mrs. Robinson was not accompanied by valuable consideration.Â  For example, Mrs. Robinson testified she has no recollection of actually transferring the stated consideration of $5.00.Â  Moreover,the Robinsonsâ€™ testimony indicates the couple did not have a clear understanding as to what constituted the consideration.Â  Mrs. Robinson stated she gave â€œall of [her] years being married to himâ€ as consideration for the property.Â  Mr. Robinson never testified as to what he considered consideration, and instead asserted he was afraid if he did not convey his interest in the property to Mrs. Robinson, the family would lose everything because of his addiction to alcohol.Â  Mr. Robinson stated he â€œwas looking out for [his] kidsâ€ and hoped this conveyance would save his marriage. Â Â 
The Robinsonsâ€™ additional claim that they conveyed the property pursuant to the separation agreement simply holds no weight.Â  The Robinsons did not separate until over a year after the conveyance, and Mr. Robinson testified he was attempting to avoid a separation in March of 2002.Â  In fact, there was testimony that Mr. Robinson may have still been living at the marital residence at the time the current declaratory action was commenced.Â  We find no consideration was exchanged in the conveyance.Â  
The absence of consideration does not end our inquiry.Â  Where a transfer is made without valuable consideration being exchanged, the transfer will be set aside only when the creditor establishes the following: (1) the grantor was indebted to the creditor at the time of the transfer; (2) the conveyance was voluntary; and (3) the grantor failed to retain sufficient property to pay his indebtedness to the creditor in full, not merely at the time of transfer, but in the final analysis when the creditor seeks to collect the debt.Â  Mathis v. Burton, 319 S.C. 261, 265, 460 S.E.2d 406, 408 (Ct. App. 1995).Â Â Â  
We must, therefore, determine whether the Albertsons were â€œexisting creditorsâ€ at the time of the March 1, 2002 conveyance.Â  The case of Matthews v. Montgomery, 193 S.C. 118, 133, 7 S.E.2d 841, 848 (1940) is instructive.Â  Matthews states that it does not matter whether a creditor obtained the judgment against a property owner before the conveyance:

It is only necessary that the debt should have been in existence or the right of action have accrued at or before the time of the transfer.Â  It may be reduced to judgment at a later date.Â  To determine whether a person is such an existing creditor as can invoke the protection of the statute the inception of the debt or obligation is the time which controls; and not the date of the subsequent entry of judgment.

Id.Â Â 
â€œThe inception of the debt or obligationâ€ arose in 2000 when Mr. Robinson breached his contract with the Albertsons. The challenged conveyance came much later on March 1, 2002, after entry of default in the underlying breach of contract action.Â  Application of Mathis and Matthews obliges us to find that the Albertsons were existing creditors at the time of the March 1, 2002 conveyance. 
The second prong shown in Mathis, that the conveyance be voluntary, is not in dispute.Â  The conveyance was voluntary.Â  
The third and final prong of Mathis requires a determination of whether sufficient funds existed to pay the judgment after the conveyance.Â  If the debtor retains sufficient assets to satisfy the debt in full, the challenged conveyance will not be set aside.Â  See Gardner v. Kirven, 184 S.C. 37, 42, 191 S.E. 814, 816-17 (1937).Â  
Mr. Robinsonâ€™s belief that the judgment would be between seven and ten thousand dollars is of no moment; however, he did not even maintain sufficient funds to pay this amount.Â  Mr. Robinson testified he transferred his interest in the house to his wife because he was afraid he was going to lose everything, and it was â€œthe last little bit I had.Â  You know, there wasnâ€™t much there.â€Â  He further testified that when he transferred the house, he did not keep anything other than his clothes.Â  He stated he anticipated there would be a judgment against him, and while he thought he would be able to borrow enough money to pay the judgment, he did not have sufficient funds in the bank.Â  Mr. Robinson apparently sold some tools, but he received around only $7,000 from the sale.Â  Therefore, the evidence establishes that Mr. Robinson failed to retain sufficient assets to satisfy his debt in full to the Albertsons.Â Â  
IV.
Accordingly, pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth, we find the March 1, 2002 conveyance void as fraudulent.Â  We reverse and remand for further proceedings.
 REVERSED and REMANDED.
 ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Ex Parte: Johnson v. Moore
description: A property was sold, by way of court order, subject to the successful bidder paying the past due property taxes and assessments. The successful bidder sought to defeat the order and avoid responsibility for the taxes. The Master followed the order. We affirm.
text:
Ex Parte Johnson


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ex Parte:
Bruce Johnson, Appellant,
In Re:
Bank of America, N.A., Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Schuyler L. Moore and Yvonne R. Moore, as Trustees for the Moore Family Trust; Schuyler L. Moore and Yvonne R. Moore; Lyn-Rich Contracting Company, Inc.; Alice
Guillemet; Scott Moore; Raymond Guillemet; Gordon Rockwell; Barbara Moore; Leslie
Guillemet; Shawn G. Guillemet; Brandy G. Guillemet; Andre S. Moore; and Deanna M. Moore,
Defendants,
Of whom Schuyler L. Moore and Yvonne R. Moore, as Trustees for the Moore Family Trust; Schuyler L. Moore and Yvonne R. Moore; Lyn-Rich Contracting Company, Inc. are the
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â JosephÂ  M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 4165
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 16, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled December 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Tobias G. Ward, Jr. and J. Derrick Jackson, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Frederick A. Gertz, John M. Aâ€™Hern and Robert F. Anderson, all of Columbia, George S. Nicholson, Jr. and Patrick J. Frawley, both of Lexington, James W. Sheedy and Susan E. Driscoll, both of Rock Hill, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  In this foreclosure action, the property was sold, by way of court order, subject to the successful bidder paying the past due property taxes and assessments.Â  The sale resulted in surplus funds.Â  Following the sale, BruceJohnson, the successful bidder, sought to defeat the previously unchallenged court order and avoid responsibility for the taxes and assessments.Â  Johnson argued to the Master, and now to us, that section 12-49-60 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) requires the payment of the taxes and assessments from the surplus funds.Â  The Master followed the order under which all parties and bidders operated and denied Johnsonâ€™s motion to satisfy the taxes and assessments from the surplus funds.Â  We affirm.
I.
Property on Lake Murray in Richland County was encumbered by a first mortgage held by Bank of America, a mechanicâ€™s lien held by Lyn-Rich Contracting Company, Inc., and a Richland County tax lien.Â  The tax lien amounted to $229,138.37, approximately one-tenth of the total value of the property.Â  The Moores, the property owners, defaulted under the mortgage for failure to make payments and Bank of America subsequently brought a foreclosure proceeding.Â  
A foreclosure hearing was held on October 27, 2004.Â  Bank of America, Lyn-Rich, and the Moores executed a Consent Order for Foreclosure and Sale.Â  The foreclosure order granted Bank of America judgment against the Moores, including the right to foreclose the mortgage and judicially sell the property.Â  In addition, the foreclosure order specifically provided that â€œthe purchaser [is] required to pay . . . for any property taxes or assessment due and payable.â€Â  
On December 30, 2004, before the scheduled date of the foreclosure sale, the Moores filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. The Bankruptcy Court granted Bank of America relief from the automatic stay to complete the foreclosure in accordance with state law.Â  The property was then advertised pursuant to a Second Notice of Sale on May 14, 21, and 28, 2005.[1]Â  
On July 6, 2005, the property was sold.Â  All prospective bidders had notice of the provision requiring the purchaser to pay the property taxes.Â  Bids were made on this basis.Â  Johnson was the highest bidder.Â  He purchased the property for $2.2 million dollars, which resulted in surplus funds.Â  
Johnson made the required five percent deposit on July 6, and by July 26 had deposited the remainder of the purchase price with the Court, at which point the Master issued a deed.Â  This deed, consistent with the prior order, also noted the property was â€œsubject to assessments, Richland County taxes, existing easements, easements and restrictions of record, and other senior encumbrances.â€Â  Johnson filed his deed for the property on August 2, 2005. 
Following the sale and after delivery of the deed, Johnson sought to defeat the foreclosure order and avoid his obligation to pay the taxes and related assessments.Â  Johnson filed a motion, pursuant to section 12-49-60 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), in an attempt to have the taxes and assessments paid from the surplus proceeds.Â  The Master issued an Order of Disbursement and denied Johnsonâ€™s motion.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 II.
The express terms of sale, established in the foreclosure order, set the property for sale subject to outstanding tax liens.Â  The foreclosure order stated the purchaser would be required to pay â€œany property taxes or assessments due and payable.â€Â  This was confirmed, without challenge, at the public commencement of the sale on June 6 when all present were reminded that the property would be sold subject to any outstanding property taxes.Â  The Masterâ€™s deed issued to Johnson on July 26 also stated the property was â€œsubject to assessments, Richland County taxes, existing easements, easements and restrictions of record, and other senior encumbrances.â€Â  Thus, by the express terms of the sale, Johnson and all other bidders understood that liability for the outstanding tax liens would fall to the successful bidder.
Under these specific facts, we concur with the Master that it would be inequitable to allow Johnson to profit from his late motion.Â  See BB & T of S. C. v. Kidwell, 350 S.C. 382, 387, 565 S.E.2d 316, 319 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œAn action to foreclose a real estate mortgage is an action in equity.â€); see also 
QHG of Lake City, Inc. v. McCutcheon, 360 S.C. 196, 202, 600 S.E.2d 105, 107 (Ct. App. 2004) (stating that while an appellate court is free to take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence in an action in equity, the court is not required to
disregard the judgeâ€™s findings).Â  
At every stage of the proceedings, all interested parties were made aware that the property was being sold subject to tax liens.Â  As noted, the foreclosure order specifically provided that â€œthe purchaser [is] required to pay . . . for any property taxes or assessment due and payable.â€Â  The Second Notice of Sale followed suit by placing responsibility for the taxes and assessments on the purchaser.Â  The deed issued by the Master, which Johnson filed ten days prior to filing his motion under section 12-49-60, stated the property was â€œsubject to assessments, Richland County taxes, existing easements, easements and restrictions of record, and other senior encumbrances.â€Â  
To rewrite the terms of sale after the sale would be patently inequitable, especially to the other bidders who made bids knowing that a successful bid would result in the additional responsibility of approximately $230,000 in past due taxes.Â  Johnsonâ€™s post sale motion pursuant to section 12-49-60 came too late.Â  By that time, Johnson had participated in the sale under the terms of the foreclosure order, failed to make any motion prior to sale, and filed a deed which further acknowledged the terms of sale.
Assuming Johnson may have invoked section 12-49-60 prior to the sale, equity must intervene when Johnson remained silent while all bidders made bids based on the additional responsibility for the payment of the substantial past due taxes and assessments.Â  Equity will not permit such an unwarranted windfall to Johnson under these circumstances.Â  See generally Collins v. Sigmon, 299 S.C. 464, 468, 385 S.E.2d 835, 837-38 (1989) (applying the ancient maxim â€œequity aids the vigilant and diligentâ€ and not those who sleep on their rights).
Furthermore, it is the long-established policy in South Carolina that â€œ[t]he courts should be particularly jealous of the integrity of judicial sales.â€Â  In re Wilson, 141 S.C. 60, 63, 139 S.E. 171, 172 (1927).Â  â€œ[A]ny conduct on the part of those actively engaged in the selling or bidding [at a judicial sale] that tends to prevent a fair, free, open sale, or stifle or suppress free competition among bidders, is contrary to public policy[.]â€Â  Ex parte Keller, 185 S.C. 283, 291, 194 S.E. 15, 19 (1937).Â  The filing of a motion under section 12-49-60 after the sale is contrary to such public policy under the circumstances here.Â  Where all parties and potential bidders in a foreclosure sale have notice of, and do not challenge, a valid court order assigning responsibility for outstanding taxes to the successful bidder as a condition of the purchase, the successful bidder may not thereafter gain a windfall by a tardy attempt to invoke section 12-49-60. 
 III. 
We further disagree with Johnsonâ€™s argument that disbursement of sale proceeds must always track section 12-49-60.Â  We find that the payment of taxes and related assessments from the sale proceeds under section 12-49-60 is not mandatory.Â  Section 12-49-60 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides:

When any real estate shall be sold under any writ, order or proceeding in any court, the court shall, on motion of any person interested in such real estate or in the purchase or proceeds of the sale thereof, order all taxes, assessments and penalties charged thereon to be paid out of the proceeds of such sale as a lien prior to all others.

The statute is not self-executingâ€”it requires a â€œmotion of any interested person . . . [w]hen any real estate shall be sold.â€  The statute does not take effect unless a timely motion is made by an interested party.  Just as section 12-49-60 protects and assigns priority to a tax lien, the consent order of foreclosure in this case protected the tax lien of Richland County.  Thus, the policy underlying section 12-49-60 is similarly achieved by giving efficacy to the foreclosure order before us today.Â  The foreclosure order here is in accord with well-established South Carolina lawâ€”â€œreal property subject to taxes cannot be sold in foreclosure free of the existing tax liens, unless provision for payment is made and they are paid.â€Â  Trustees of Wofford College v. Burnett, 209 S.C. 92, 107, 39 S.E.2d 155, 161 (1946).Â  This was the law of the land in 1881, at the time the predecessor to section 12-49-60 was originally passed.Â  See Smith v. Gatewood, 3 S.C. 333, 334 (1872) (finding purchaser of real estate purchased subject to tax lien when no provision provided otherwise and taxing authority not party to sale of property); See also 47 Am. Jur. 2d Judicial Sales Â§ 160 (2006) (â€œThe rule that, absent an express stipulation to the contrary in the terms of sale, a purchaser takes the property subject to valid liens ordinarily applies to liens for taxes and assessments accruing prior to the confirmation of the sale or arising after the completion of the sale.â€).
Johnson argues Truesdale v. Bellinger, 172 S.C. 80, 172 S.E. 784 (1934), mandates a contrary result.  We disagree.Â  In Truesdale, property was sold by the probate court in aid of assets.  Id.Â  There, the probate court notified all bidders before the sale that all debts of the estate would be paid from the proceeds.  Id. at 85, 172 S.E. at 786.Â  When the taxes due on the land were not paid from the proceeds, the successful bidder brought an action against the probate judge.  Id.Â  Although our supreme court ultimately ruled the probate judge made an error of law in his judicial capacity that was not actionable, the court noted that a motion for payment of taxes from the proceeds of a sale (pursuant to the predecessor to section 12-49-60) may be made after the sale but before the disbursement of the proceeds.Â  Id. at 87, 172 S.E. at 787.Â  Unlike in the instant case, however, payment of the taxes due in Truesdale out of the proceeds from the sale would not have changed the terms of the sale upon which the bidders had relied in making their bids.Â  We thus find Truesdale distinguishable, for application of section 12-49-60 here after the sale, would alter the terms of the sale upon which all bidders relied in making their bids.
IV.
The judgment of the Master is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  We further note that the Second Notice of Sale also addressed payment of taxes, ordering that â€œthe purchaser be required to pay . . . for any property taxes which become due and payable after the date of sale[.]â€Â  We view this Second Notice of Sale as consistent with the foreclosure order.Â  Even assuming, however, that there is a conflict between the terms of the foreclosure order and Second Notice of Sale, the law is settled that the foreclosure order controls.Â  See Bonney v. Granger, 300 S.C. 362, 364, 387 S.E.2d 720, 722 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œ[t]he Notice of Sale does not set forth the conditions of sale, but refers to the prior order authorizing the sale.â€).
